pile hitch: A specialized hitch used to secure a rope to a post or pile, particularly when the pull is parallel to the post. Look for the wraps around the object that increase grip as tension is applied. This hitch is designed specifically for vertical posts or piles.
leg cutter: A delivery from a medium-pace bowler where the ball cuts or moves away from a right-handed batsman after pitching. Look for fingers dragged down the side of the ball at release and movement away from the batsman off the pitch.
romanian deadlift (rdl): Standing holding a barbell or dumbbells in front of the thighs, lowering the weight towards the ground by hinging primarily at the hips, keeping the back straight and knees only slightly bent, feeling a stretch in the hamstrings, then returning to the upright position by extending the hips. Look for: a person bending forward at the hips with straight legs (slight knee bend okay), lowering a weight down the front of their legs.
muscle up: A strength-based movement where the practitioner pulls themselves from a hanging position on a bar to being on top of it in one fluid motion. Look for the transition from hanging to supporting without using kipping motions.
heeling in: Temporarily storing dormant, bare-root plants (which are... inactive plants sold with exposed roots) by digging a shallow trench, placing the plants at an angle with roots in the trench, and covering the roots with moist soil. Look for: dormant, stick-like plants laid slanted in a ditch with only their roots buried in soil.
satin stitch: A solid filling embroidery stitch made with closely placed parallel stitches that completely cover an area of fabric. The stitches lie flat and close together, creating a smooth, satin-like surface. Look for areas completely covered with smooth, parallel threads that reflect light like satin, often used to fill shapes or create solid areas in embroidery.
straight drive: A front-foot batting shot played to a full delivery on the stumps, with the batsman driving the ball straight back past the bowler. Look for the forward stride, high elbow, and straight bat swing down the ground.
slipped overhand knot: A variation of the overhand knot where a bight is used instead of the working end, creating a quick-release version. Look for the loop (slip) that allows for instant untying with a pull. This modification turns the basic overhand into a convenient temporary knot.
overhand knot: The simplest of all knots, formed by creating a loop and passing the working end through it. Look for the basic single crossing of the rope over itself. This fundamental knot serves as the basis for many other knots but is not particularly secure on its own.
glazing: A technique where thin, transparent layers of paint are applied over previously dried layers to modify, enhance, or deepen colors. Each transparent layer allows light to pass through to the underlying colors, creating luminosity and depth not achievable with a single layer. Glazing requires complete drying between applications and works best with transparent pigments. Look for the rich, luminous quality and depth created by visible layers of color building upon one another.
backside flip: A combination trick where the skater performs a kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis) while rotating their body and board 180 degrees backside (rotation where the skater's back faces the direction of travel). Look for the simultaneous rotation and flip.
between the legs dunk: A spectacular dunk where the player passes the ball between their legs while in mid-air before dunking it. Look for the ball traveling between the legs during the jump before being slammed through the hoop.
popcorn stitch: A dimensional stitch made by working multiple complete double crochets into the same stitch, then removing the hook from the last stitch, inserting it into the first stitch, and pulling through to close the group. This creates a pronounced, rounded bump on the fabric. Look for the distinct ball-like projections that pop out from the surface.
parry: A defensive action where the fencer blocks or deflects the opponent's attacking blade using the forte (strong part) of their own blade. There are eight basic parry positions, each covering different lines of attack. A successful parry in foil and sabre transfers right-of-way to the defender. Look for the deliberate blade movement that intercepts and blocks the incoming attack.
slurp: A fast, precise step where one foot hits the floor first with the ball, then the heel, then the ball again. The dancer creates three quick sounds in succession with the same foot. Look for the rapid toe-heel-toe sequence with minimal movement. This differs from other multiple-sound steps by the specific ball-heel-ball pattern on a single foot.
false start: A penalty where an offensive player moves after getting set but before the ball is snapped. Look for a sudden movement by an offensive player followed by an immediate whistle stopping the play.
julienne: A knife cutting technique that creates thin matchstick-shaped strips, typically 1/8 inch thick and about 2 inches long. This precise cut is used for even cooking and attractive presentation of vegetables and fruits. Look for the uniform, thin rectangular strips resembling matchsticks.
coral stitch: A line stitch that creates a series of small knots along a drawn line, also known as German Knot stitch or Snail Trail. The stitch is worked by making small diagonal stitches with a knot formed by looping the thread around the needle before inserting it back into the fabric. Look for the characteristic line of evenly spaced knots that create a textured outline. This stitch is excellent for outlining shapes, stems, and curves in a decorative manner.
exhibela: A basic figure in Cuban salsa where the follow is showcased through specific walking patterns. The follow walks a specific pattern while the lead directs the movement, often including an inside or outside turn. Look for the follow being "exhibited" or showcased during this movement.
flash: A brief demonstration of juggling skill where all balls are thrown once and caught once. This is not a sustained pattern but rather a single cycle of throws and catches. Look for all the balls being thrown into the air at once and then caught in sequence.
pull whip shading: A shading technique where the needle grouping (often round shaders or liners, which are... needles grouped in a circle) enters the skin and is quickly flicked out and away from the direction of the hand movement (pulling the machine towards the body often results in the flick moving away). This creates a gradient that starts darker where the needle enters and fades out to dots or lighter tones where it leaves the skin. Look for: the artist making quick, flicking motions away from the main shaded area or line, often pulling the machine towards themselves, leaving a trail of ink that diminishes into dots or lighter shading.
running into the kicker: A less severe penalty than roughing where a defender makes minor contact with a kicker. Look for a defender making minor or incidental contact with the kicker after the kick.
decrease / single crochet decrease: A technique to reduce the number of stitches in a row by working two stitches together as one. For a single crochet decrease, you insert your hook into one stitch, pull up a loop, then without completing the stitch, insert into the next stitch, pull up another loop, and complete both together. Look for areas where the fabric narrows or tapers.
balanc\u00e9: A rocking, waltz-like movement that shifts weight from one foot to the other in a three-count rhythm (down, up, down). The dancer typically moves side to side or forward and backward while maintaining an elegant, swaying motion. Look for the graceful, pendulum-like quality of the movement.
hunter's bend: A bend knot used to join two ropes securely. It consists of two interlocking overhand knots configured so their working ends emerge on the same side. Look for the symmetrical interlocking pattern with parallel ends. This knot is secure and maintains strength even under heavy loads.
tonic seizure: A brief seizure marked predominantly by sudden stiffening and increased muscle tone causing sustained muscle contractions. The body typically tightens abruptly, causing the arms or legs to straighten rigidly, and potentially causing balance issues or falls. They generally last seconds to about one minute.
finger pass: A fundamental sequence where the pen rotates 0.5 times (half a rotation) between consecutive finger slots (spaces between fingers), moving sequentially across all fingers to make a complete circuit of the hand. The pen travels from slot 12 to 23 to 34 and so on with half spins. Look for the pen methodically moving from one finger slot to the next with partial rotations. This differs from backaround fall by using simple half-rotation passes instead of full around spins.
cross shading: Building up tones and gradients (which are... smooth transitions between dark and light) by layering lines over each other, typically at different angles (like cross-hatching in drawing). Lighter areas have fewer, more spaced lines, while darker areas have multiple layers of overlapping lines. Look for: the artist making distinct linear strokes with the needle, then layering more lines over them, often in a perpendicular or angled direction, creating a textured, shaded effect built from lines.
impossible: A complex trick where the board wraps around the back foot in a scooping motion (the board rotates vertically wrapped around the foot). Look for the distinctive vertical wraparound motion different from a standard flip.
center pour: A pouring technique in pour-over coffee where hot water is poured in a steady, pencil-thin stream directly into the center of the coffee bed. Look for the water stream remaining fixed in the middle of the coffee grounds throughout the entire pour rather than moving in spiral or circular motions.
sarikkal adavu / sarukkal adavu: A sliding movement where one foot glides along the floor while the other follows. "Sarikkal" means "to slide" in Tamil. The dancer slides one foot forward, then lifts the other foot with the heel raised, brings both feet together with a slight jump, and lands with heels raised. To identify this movement, look for the smooth gliding action of the feet followed by the characteristic heel-raised position (called Anchita) at the end.
camel spin: A spin where the skater spins on one foot with the free leg extended straight behind the body, parallel to the ice at hip level, creating an arabesque-like position. The body should form a horizontal line.
sprung cascade: A four-ball pattern that combines the three-ball cascade with a fourth ball being passed between hands with every throw. It can also be thought of as a Box with vertical throws replaced by cascade throws. Look for three balls in a cascade pattern with a fourth ball being passed horizontally.
pancake: A downward inversion stunt where the flyer performs a forward fold while their legs remain in the grip of the bases, landing on their back while still being held. Look for the pike forward motion with the flyer ending up horizontal and face-down.
ribbing: A textured technique that creates elastic fabric with pronounced vertical or horizontal ridges. It's typically made using front and back post stitches or by working in specific loops of stitches from previous rows. Look for the raised parallel ridges that resemble knitted ribbing and provide stretch.
diving save: A technique where a goalkeeper jumps sideways through the air to prevent a shot from entering the goal (using hands and arms to block or catch the ball). Look for the goalkeeper launching horizontally to reach a shot.
the factory: A trick where one arm carries a ball over the entire pattern and drops it as if on an assembly line. It's best performed with rigid, robotic arm movements (also known as "The Robot"). Look for the mechanical arm movement carrying one ball over the pattern.
slip stitch: A nearly invisible stitch used to join folded edges of fabric, attach appliqués, or close openings. The needle catches only a thread or two from each folded edge, creating a join that can barely be seen. Look for the minuscule stitches that are barely visible on the right side. This practical stitch is essential for fine finishing work and anywhere an invisible join is required.
stretch and fold: A gentle bread dough development technique where the dough is stretched out and folded back onto itself multiple times during the rising period. This builds strength and structure without overworking the dough. Look for the pulling and folding motion that creates layers in the dough.
mazurka jump: A small, one-foot hop jump where the skater takes off from one foot and lands on the other. Not one of the six main rotational jumps.
mandi adavu: A physically demanding movement where the dancer transitions between standing and full sitting positions. "Mandi" refers to the knee or sitting position. The dancer lowers their body to a complete sitting position with their entire weight balanced on the toes, then rises back to standing, all while maintaining coordination with arm gestures. To identify this movement, look for the deep squat position with the dancer's body weight balanced perfectly on the balls of the feet, requiring tremendous leg strength and balance.
back spot turn: A turn where the dancer rotates 360 degrees in place while stepping backward on count 1. The dancer pivots on the ball of the foot while maintaining the same spot on the dance floor. Look for the rotation occurring in a fixed position with the initial backward step.
titanic: A pattern where partners face the same direction with the follow typically in front of the lead in tandem position. Often combined with different exits and variations like the half titanic or walkback titanic. Look for the characteristic "ship" position with both partners facing the same direction.
blake's hitch: A friction hitch used primarily by arborists for ascending and descending ropes. The knot grips when weight is applied in one direction but can be adjusted by hand when unloaded. Look for four wraps around the main rope with the working end tucked back through the first two wraps. Only use this knot when the strain is applied to the line below the hitch, not on the knot itself.
fake columns: A variation of columns where the pattern appears to be in columns but actually involves throwing between hands. The juggler creates the illusion of columns while still transferring balls from hand to hand. Look for what appears to be columns but with hand transfers on catches.
hurdler jump: A jump with two variations - front hurdler and side hurdler. In both, one leg is straight while the other is bent. In the front hurdler, the straight leg extends forward with the bent leg behind. In the side hurdler, the straight leg extends to the side with the bent knee facing the crowd. Look for the distinct straight-bent leg position.
reducing: The process of simmering or boiling a liquid to decrease its volume through evaporation, which concentrates flavors and thickens the consistency. Often used for sauces, stocks, and glazes. Look for the visibly diminished volume and more intense color of the liquid.
blanching: A quick cooking method where food (typically vegetables or fruits) is briefly immersed in boiling water, then immediately plunged into ice water to halt the cooking process. This preserves color, texture, and nutrients while making it easier to peel some foods. Look for the two-step process of hot water followed by cold water.
behind the back dribble: A dribbling technique (bouncing the ball continuously with one hand) where the player bounces the ball behind their back from one hand to the other to avoid a defender. Look for the ball moving behind the player's body during the dribble.
blocking below the waist: A penalty where a player blocks an opponent at or below the waist in situations where it's prohibited. Look for a blocker diving or lunging at the legs/knees of an opponent.
fumble: When a player with possession of the ball loses it before being ruled down or scoring. Look for the ball coming loose while a player is still in the act of running, passing, or being tackled.
attitude: A position where the dancer stands on one leg with the other leg lifted and bent at approximately a 90-degree angle, either to the front (devant) or back (derrière). Unlike arabesque, the working leg is bent rather than straight. Look for the bent knee and curved line created by the working leg.
rolling hitch: A friction hitch used to attach a rope to another rope or pole, particularly effective when the pull is parallel to the object rather than at right angles. Look for the series of turns that create directional gripping power. This hitch is designed to resist slipping along the object even under tension.
alpine stitch: A textured stitch pattern created by alternating rows of front post double crochet with rows of single crochet. The front post stitches are worked around posts from two rows below, creating raised diagonal patterns that resemble mountain ranges. Look for the characteristic elevated ridges that form diamond-like textures across the fabric.
reverse cross body lead: Similar to the cross body lead but performed in the opposite direction. The couple exchanges positions in a clockwise fashion rather than the counter-clockwise movement of a standard cross body lead. Look for the clockwise exchange of positions between dancers.
cat leap: A jumping technique where the practitioner leaps toward a vertical obstacle, catching the top edge with their hands while landing their feet against the wall to absorb impact (also known as arm jump). Look for the distinctive landing position with hands on top and feet against the surface.
lbw (leg before wicket): A method of dismissal where the ball would have hit the stumps but is intercepted by the batsman's body (usually the leg). Look for the ball striking the batsman's pad or body when it was on track to hit the wicket.
munchmill: A power move similar to a windmill but performed with the legs tucked in rather than extended. The tighter body position allows for faster rotation. Look for the compact spinning motion with bent legs.
googly: A deceptive delivery bowled by a leg-spinner that spins in the opposite direction to a normal leg-break (turning from off to leg for a right-handed batsman). Look for the back of the hand facing the batsman at delivery with the ball turning unexpectedly.
bullion stitch: An advanced crochet technique where multiple yarn overs are wrapped around the hook before pulling through all loops at once. This creates a long, coiled or rolled appearance resembling a French knot. The stitch is challenging to master due to the difficulty of pulling the yarn through many loops simultaneously. Bullion stitches add unique texture and are commonly used in freeform crochet, flowers, and intricate designs. Also called the roll stitch, it requires practice to achieve consistent tension and appearance.
ace: A serve that lands inside the service box and is not touched by the receiver, resulting in an immediate point for the server. Look for the ball landing cleanly in the service box without the opponent making any contact with their racquet. This differs from a regular serve winner because an ace specifically means the opponent doesn't touch the ball at all.
white buddha: A complex, advanced 1A string trick involving intricate string maneuvers and multiple mount transitions beginning typically from "Double or Nothing." Visually engaging, as the yo-yo moves through complicated and precise loops, twists, and flips around multiple string segments, creating a rhythmic flowing pattern. Clearly distinguished from simpler tricks by length, intricacy, and elegant, layered string interactions.
arabesque: A stunt position where the flyer (person in the air) stands on one leg with the other leg extended straight behind them, arms typically extended out to the sides in a T position, creating a graceful horizontal line with the body. Look for the stunt group facing to the side with the flyer's back leg raised parallel to the ground or higher.
one-timer: A shot taken immediately upon receiving a pass without stopping the puck first. The fluid motion between pass reception and shot execution gives goaltenders minimal time to position themselves.
buntline hitch: A knot used to attach a rope to a post, rail, ring, or other object. The knot consists of a turn around the object followed by a clove hitch around the standing part. Look for the distinctive pattern where the clove hitch progresses toward the object being tied to. This knot is particularly secure against shaking loose, making it valuable for nautical applications.
nattadavu 8: The most complex of the stretching movements, combining elements of all previous Nattadavu variations with additional crossing patterns. The dancer performs leg extensions, turns, level changes, and crossings of the legs in a sophisticated sequence. The arm movements are correspondingly complex, creating an intricate visual display. To identify this movement, look for the crossing of legs combined with turns and level changes, representing the culmination of the Nattadavu progression.
tandem gait (heel to toe): Assessing balance and coordination by having the person walk in a straight line, placing the heel of the front foot directly against the toes of the back foot with each step, as if walking on a tightrope. Look for: the person walking heel-to-toe along a line; note their ability to maintain balance, stay on the line, and place their feet accurately.
friction: Deep, focused movements, often circular or transverse (which is... moving across the grain of the muscle fibers), applied with fingertips, thumb, or heel of the hand directly to a specific area, rubbing one layer of tissue against deeper layers often without much lubricant. Look for: therapist pressing firmly into a specific spot and making small, repetitive rubbing or circular motions without sliding much over the skin surface.
halo: A power move where the dancer spins on their head and shoulders with their legs extended outward. Similar to a headspin but with rotation occurring on both the head and upper back. Look for the rolling motion around the upper body with extended legs.
carrom ball: A special delivery bowled by off-spinners where the ball is flicked between the thumb and bent middle finger (similar to flicking a carrom piece in the board game). Look for an unusual release with the ball spinning in the opposite direction to the bowler's normal delivery.
boardslide: A slide trick (which is when part of the skateboard slides along an object) where the skater ollie's (jumps with the board) onto an obstacle and slides sideways with the board's deck (bottom surface of the board) making contact with the edge or rail. Look for the board perpendicular to the obstacle with the middle of the deck sliding.
block in the back: A penalty where a player blocks an opponent by pushing or contacting them from behind. Look for a blocker's hands clearly pushing against the back area of a defender.
spiral: A position where a skater keeps one foot on the ice and extends the free leg above hip level. Look for the extended free leg to be at hip height or higher.
toe walking: Assessing balance and specific muscle strength (plantar flexors) by having the person walk a short distance only on the balls of their feet or toes, keeping their heels off the ground. Look for: the person walking with weight only on their toes/forefeet; note their balance and ability to keep the heels elevated.
tripping: A penalty called when a player uses their stick, knee, foot, arm, or hand to cause an opponent to fall. This action interferes with an opponent's ability to maintain balance and control.
scumbling: A technique where a small amount of opaque or semi-opaque paint is applied with a nearly dry brush in a circular or irregular motion over dried underlying layers. Unlike glazing, scumbling uses thicker paint applied inconsistently, creating a broken, textured effect that partially reveals the colors beneath. This technique is excellent for creating atmospheric effects, texture, or softening transitions between areas. Look for the characteristic broken, scattered application of lighter paint over darker areas.
devils sonic: A hybrid trick combining a twisted sonic (which is a 1.5 rotation transfer between finger slots using combined charge and pass motions) with a shadow (which is a charge-fingerspin-charge sequence). The pen moves from slot 23 to 12 with extended middle finger creating a distinctive hand position. Look for the pen traveling from bottom to top finger slots with the characteristic middle finger extension. This differs from a regular twisted sonic by adding the shadow component and the specific finger position.
finger rolls: A flair bartending technique where a bottle or bar tool is manipulated to roll across and between the fingers of one hand. The object maintains constant contact with the fingers while being smoothly passed from one finger to another, creating a fluid, dexterous display that showcases the bartender's hand control and precision.
coca-cola: A left turn in Cuban salsa, where the dancer rotates counterclockwise. This is a basic figure of one count of eight with the same pattern as right turns except turning in the left direction. Look for the counterclockwise rotation, which is less common in salsa than right turns.
alley-oop: An offensive play where one player throws a high pass near the basket for a teammate who jumps, catches the ball in mid-air, and immediately scores (usually with a dunk) before landing. Look for the coordinated timing between the passer and receiver.
chest fly: Lying on a bench or using a machine/cables, starting with weights/handles held above the chest with arms mostly straight, lowering the arms out to the sides in a wide arc (like hugging a large tree), then bringing them back together over the chest. Look for: a wide, arcing motion of the arms opening and closing across the chest, typically while lying down or seated at a machine.
muddling: The process of crushing ingredients like fruits, herbs, or sugar in the bottom of a glass to release their flavors. The bartender uses a muddler (a tool similar to a pestle) to press and twist the ingredients against the bottom of the glass, extracting essential oils and juices that enhance the cocktail's flavor profile.
challenge flag: A physical red flag thrown onto the field by a head coach to challenge an official's ruling on the previous play. Look for a coach deliberately reaching into their pocket/sock and throwing a red flag onto the field.
rock and roll: A transition trick (which is performed on curved ramps) where the skater approaches a quarter pipe or coping (the metal edge at the top of a ramp), places the front truck over the lip (top edge of the ramp), then turns 180 degrees and returns down the ramp. Look for the distinctive front-truck-over-then-turnaround motion.
soubresaut: A jump from two feet to two feet without changing the position of the feet in the air. The legs remain tightly together throughout the jump. The term means "sudden jump." Look for the tight, unchanged position of the feet during the elevation.
balestra lunge: A combined forward movement starting with a short forward jump (balestra) immediately followed by a lunge. The balestra involves a small jump where both feet land together, heels off the floor, which increases the elasticity in the legs for the immediately following lunge. This technique alters the tempo of the fencing phrase and can catch opponents off-guard. Look for the characteristic small jump followed by a powerful lunge.
rapid alternating movements: Testing coordination (similar to Dysdiadochokinesia test) by having the person perform repetitive alternating actions quickly, such as slapping their thighs with alternating palm-up/palm-down movements, or rapidly tapping fingers or feet. Look for: the person performing quick, repetitive, back-and-forth movements with hands or feet; observe the speed, smoothness, and rhythm.
star stitch: A complex decorative stitch that creates star-shaped patterns across the fabric. It involves working multiple partial stitches together to form the points of a star. Look for the distinctive star or flower-like clusters with 5-6 "points" radiating from a center "eye."
tapotement hacking: Rapid, alternating strikes using the ulnar border (the edge of the hand by the little finger, like a light "karate chop"), with wrists kept loose and relaxed. A form of tapotement (which is... a category of rapid, rhythmic, percussive massage strokes). Look for: therapist quickly and alternately striking the client's muscles using the sides of their open hands.
fakie big flip: A trick performed while riding fakie (backward) that combines a 360-degree shuvit (horizontal board rotation) with a kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis). Look for the fakie stance with the big flip motion.
couching stitch: A technique where one thread is laid on the fabric surface and held in place by small stitches worked over it in a perpendicular direction with a second thread. The base thread can be thick, metallic, or textured, allowing for special threads to be showcased that might be too thick to pass through the fabric. Look for a main thread lying on the surface with small, regular anchoring stitches crossing over it. This stitch is especially popular in goldwork embroidery and for creating decorative outlines.
single crochet: The most basic and shortest of the standard crochet stitches. It's formed by inserting the hook into a stitch, pulling up a loop, and drawing yarn through both loops on the hook. Look for the short, dense stitches that create a firm fabric.
double axel: An axel jump with two and a half rotations in the air. Look for the forward takeoff characteristic of all axel jumps.
headbutt: An illegal action where a player uses their head to direct the puck or make contact with an opponent. This dangerous move results in a major penalty and game misconduct.
between-the-legs shot: A creative shot where the player passes the puck between their own legs before shooting. This deceptive move can catch defenders and goaltenders off guard as it changes the angle and timing of the shot.
swirling: A gentler form of agitation that involves moving the entire brewing vessel or milk pitcher in a circular motion. With coffee, this ensures even extraction by distributing water evenly; with steamed milk, it integrates microfoam throughout the liquid to create a silky texture. Look for the barista moving the entire vessel in a circular motion without using any additional tools.
tomahawk dunk: A powerful dunk where the player raises the ball high behind their head (like a tomahawk) before forcefully slamming it through the hoop. Look for the arm cocked back with the ball behind the head before dunking.
hitch kick double basket: A basket toss where the flyer performs a hitch kick motion (switching legs in the air) followed by a double twist before being caught. Look for the alternating leg kicks combined with two rotations in the air.
munter hitch: A versatile friction hitch used in climbing and rescue situations as a belay method. It allows control of a loaded line and can be tied quickly without specialized equipment. Look for the simple "S" shaped formation around a carabiner that provides excellent friction control. This hitch dynamically controls rope movement through friction.
dry brushing: A painting technique where minimal paint is applied to a dry brush, then dragged across the surface with light pressure to create textured, broken strokes. The technique leaves some of the underlying surface visible, as paint only adheres to raised areas. Dry brushing is excellent for creating texture, highlighting details, and adding dimension to surfaces. Look for the characteristic scratchy, rough appearance where the texture of the surface shows through the paint strokes.
feather stitch: A decorative embroidery stitch resembling feathers or branches, made with alternating diagonal stitches that meet at a central invisible line. Each stitch extends outward at an angle, creating a feathery, vine-like effect. Look for a series of open, V-shaped stitches arranged in an alternating pattern that creates a light, airy appearance.
continuous thumb around: Multiple consecutive thumb arounds (where the pen rotates 360 degrees around the thumb) performed without stopping, creating an ongoing rotation. Each cycle is a complete spin around the thumb, immediately followed by another. Look for the pen continuously circling the thumb without pausing between rotations. This differs from a single thumb around by the uninterrupted sequence of rotations.
emptying drip tray: The act of removing and emptying the tray that collects excess water and coffee runoff from an espresso machine. This maintenance task prevents overflow and keeps the machine clean, with some machines featuring indicators that show when the tray is full. Look for the barista removing the rectangular tray from beneath the brew group area and discarding the collected liquid.
heel hook: A technique where a climber places the heel of their foot on a hold and pulls with the hamstring muscles, effectively using the leg as an extra arm. This provides stability, prevents swinging, and reduces arm fatigue on steep terrain. Look for a climber's heel placed on a hold with their toe pointing away from it.
palm press: A technique where the climber pushes against the rock with an open palm rather than gripping with fingers, using friction and pressure for stability. This is useful on slab climbs, in corners when stemming, or when no positive holds are available. Look for a climber using their palm flat against the wall.
wrap-around goal: A scoring play where an attacking player carries the puck behind the opponent's net and quickly attempts to wrap it around the post before the goaltender can move to cover that side.
snatch: A flair bartending move where an object in mid-flight is "snatched" or intercepted using another object, typically a shaker tin. The bartender positions the catching vessel to intercept the moving object at precisely the right moment, requiring excellent timing and hand-eye coordination to execute cleanly.
biellmann spin: A spin where the skater grabs their free blade and pulls the heel of their boot behind and above the level of the head, creating a split position with the head and back arched upward. Look for the distinctive "teardrop" shape formed by the skater's body.
deadlift: Lifting a loaded barbell or dumbbells from the floor by extending the hips and knees simultaneously, keeping the back straight, until standing fully upright with shoulders back. Look for: a person lifting a weight from the floor to a standing position in one smooth motion, primarily using legs and back, starting with bent knees and hips.
back handspring: A backward tumbling movement where the practitioner jumps backward, places both hands on the ground behind them, and uses their momentum to push off and land on their feet. Look for the arc-like motion with hands touching the ground.
flat wash: A painting technique that creates a uniform, even layer of color across an area. This is achieved by applying consistent mixtures of paint with sufficient moisture, usually in horizontal strokes that slightly overlap each other, creating a smooth, solid area of color with no visible brush marks or value changes. Flat washes are commonly used for backgrounds, skies, or any area requiring solid, unvarying color. Look for the perfectly even, consistent appearance with no variation in color or tone.
yarn over: The most fundamental crochet technique where the working yarn is wrapped over the hook from back to front before pulling through loops. This action is used in virtually every crochet stitch beyond the chain stitch and creates the structure of the fabric. The number and placement of yarn overs in a stitch sequence determine the height and texture of the resulting stitch. Understanding how to properly tension and execute yarn overs is essential for maintaining consistent stitch size and fabric appearance.
fishbone stitch: A filling stitch composed of alternating diagonal stitches that overlap at the center to create a herringbone-like pattern, commonly used for filling leaf shapes. The stitch is worked from the tip of a leaf shape downward, with stitches alternating from side to side and overlapping at the center. Look for the distinctive vertebrae-like pattern that resembles a fish skeleton. This stitch gives a wonderful textural quality to leaves and pointed shapes in embroidery.
neck catch: A trick where a ball is caught on the back of the neck rather than in the hand. The ball typically lands in the space between the shoulders and head, requiring precise timing and position. Look for the deliberate positioning of the neck to receive the ball.
liberty: A fundamental stunt where the flyer stands on one leg (usually the left) with the other leg bent at the knee, held up so the foot is near the knee of the standing leg. Look for the balancing position on one leg with the other bent at approximately 90 degrees.
cross body lead: A fundamental salsa pattern where the follow crosses from one side of the lead to the other, switching positions. The lead turns a quarter-left while holding the follow, who then moves forward across the lead to face the opposite direction. Look for the exchange of positions where dancers end up on the opposite side from where they started.
brent stole: A slack trick where a loop of string is whipped around the yo-yo mid-air, instantly forming a triangular string formation known as a Green Triangle. Visually dramatic as the yo-yo seems suddenly captured by a triangle of slack string. Different from regular whips due to immediate Green Triangle formation.
interference: A penalty called when a player impedes the progress of an opponent who does not have possession of the puck. Players can only legally check opponents who directly control the puck.
thumb opposition: Assessing fine motor coordination and hand dexterity by having the person touch the tip of their thumb to the tip of each finger (index, middle, ring, little) on the same hand, sequentially and often rapidly, forwards and backwards. Look for: the person tapping their thumb tip to each fingertip in sequence; note the speed, precision, and smoothness of the movements.
colonial knot: A decorative knotted stitch that creates a rounded, raised texture on the fabric surface, commonly used in candlewicking embroidery. Similar to a French knot but larger and more secure, it's created by wrapping the thread around the needle in a figure-8 pattern before inserting back into the fabric. Look for the raised, round knots that stand prominently from the fabric. This stitch can be used for flower centers, filling areas, or creating textured patterns.
pakka adavu: A high-lifting foot movement performed from a half-sitting position. The dancer lifts one foot high, almost touching the heel to the buttock area, then firmly strikes the ground, creating a sharp sound. This alternates between right and left feet in a rhythmic pattern. To identify this movement, look for the distinctive high lifting of the foot followed by a powerful strike on the ground, creating clear rhythmic sounds.
gravity pull: Simplest yo-yo return method, where the player throws the yo-yo downward gently and pulls upward, causing immediate return. Visually looks like a simple drop and tug upward, distinct for its direct vertical motion without sleeping.
flip shot: A shot where the puck is lifted into the air using a scooping or flicking motion. This shot is often used to get the puck over a defender's stick or a sprawling goaltender.
cc: A footwork move where the dancer squats on one leg while extending the other leg out to the side, then switches legs in a fluid motion. The name "CC" comes from the circular motion created by the extended leg. Look for the characteristic sweeping leg movement while the dancer stays low to the ground.
charge reverse: A charge (continuous conical spinning in one position) performed in the opposite direction from normal. If a normal charge spins clockwise in the right hand, the reverse charge spins counterclockwise. Look for the same cone-shaped spinning motion as a regular charge but with opposite rotation. This differs from normal charge only in rotation direction, not in the basic conical spinning motion.
pogo / moon kick: A dynamic technique where the climber uses the swinging momentum of one leg to propel their body upward in an arcing motion, allowing them to reach higher holds. Unlike a dyno, this move follows an upward arc trajectory. Look for a climber swinging one leg forcefully to generate upward momentum.
laminating: The process of creating alternating layers of dough and fat (usually butter) by repeated folding and rolling. This technique creates the signature flaky layers in pastries like croissants and puff pastry. Look for the distinct layers visible in the finished baked good.
off cutter: A delivery from a medium-pace bowler where the ball cuts or moves in toward a right-handed batsman after pitching. Look for the fingers being rolled down the side of the ball at release and movement into the batsman off the pitch.
toasting: A dry-heat cooking method where items (typically bread, nuts, spices, or grains) are heated until their surface browns, creating enhanced flavor, aroma, and texture through caramelization and the Maillard reaction. This can be done in an oven, toaster, or dry pan over heat. Look for items that have developed a golden-brown color, increased aroma, and a more complex flavor profile with a firmer texture.
cramp roll: A four-sound step consisting of alternating ball taps and heel drops. The dancer steps on the ball of one foot, then the other, followed by dropping the heels in the same order. Look for the "horse gallop" rhythm and the distinct ball-ball-heel-heel pattern. This differs from other heel steps by its distinctive four-beat rhythm pattern.
inside-out forehand: A forehand stroke hit from the backhand side of the court, with the player running around their backhand to hit a forehand diagonally across the court. A tennis shot in which a player makes a forehand shot from the backhand side of the court. Look for the player moving to their backhand side to hit a crosscourt forehand.
ice carving / ice cutting: The artistic technique of shaping large blocks of ice into specific forms for cocktails or display. The bartender uses specialized tools like ice picks, chisels, or saws to craft clear ice into unique shapes, spheres, or custom pieces that not only look impressive but also melt more slowly than standard ice, minimizing drink dilution.
parkinsonian gait: A distinctive walking pattern of shorter steps, reduced arm swinging, stiffness, and stooped posture. Individuals typically move cautiously, slowly, and have difficulty initiating or turning movements, sometimes appearing as though feet are temporarily stuck to the floor ("freezing"). Parkinsonian gait is commonly associated with Parkinson’s disease or similar movement disorders.
quilter's knot: A special starting knot made by wrapping thread around the needle to create a secure anchor that can be buried within the layers of a quilt. Made at the beginning of hand quilting by twisting the needle within a thread loop. Look for a small, secure knot that can be pulled through fabric layers to hide it within the batting of a quilt.
palm spin: A trick where the pen spins horizontally on the flat surface of the palm or back of the hand, creating a balanced rotation while the hand remains relatively still (like a spinning plate). Look for the pen rotating flat against the hand surface without falling off. This differs from other spinning tricks by occurring on a flat surface rather than around fingers or between them.
jamaican flag: Picture trick forming a string pattern resembling the Jamaican flag. Visually distinctive due to its clear rectangular shape with an "X" in the middle.
nattadavu 3: A leg stretching movement that adds directional changes. The dancer extends one leg to the side, then forward, creating a more complex pattern of movements. Each leg extension is precise and deliberate, with the dancer maintaining perfect balance throughout. The corresponding arm movements enhance the geometric patterns created by the legs. To identify this movement, look for the multi-directional leg extensions executed with control and precision.
double lutz: A lutz jump with two rotations in the air. Look for the deep outside edge takeoff with toe pick assistance.
bud rubbing: Using fingers or thumbs to physically rub off small, unwanted buds (which are... undeveloped shoots appearing as bumps) from the stems or trunk of a plant, usually a woody one. Look for: a person closely inspecting a woody stem and using their thumb/fingers to remove small bumps.
tent stitch: A basic diagonal stitch used in needlepoint and canvas work, covering one intersection of canvas or fabric threads at a time. The stitch is worked diagonally from bottom right to top left (for right-handed stitchers), creating small, neat diagonal stitches. Look for the uniform diagonal stitches that completely cover the canvas or fabric. This fundamental stitch is the basis for needlepoint work and creates a strong, durable surface.
creaming: A mixing technique where softened fat (usually butter) is beaten with sugar until the mixture becomes light, fluffy, and pale in color. This incorporates air into the mixture, which helps baked goods rise and creates a tender texture. Look for the transformation from dense to fluffy, lighter-colored mixture.
triple flip: A flip jump with three rotations in the air. Look for the inside edge takeoff with toe pick assistance.
frapp\u00e9: A sharp, striking movement where the working foot quickly extends from a position at the ankle (cou-de-pied) to an extended position. The term means "struck" or "to strike." Look for the quick, sharp movement of the working foot as it strikes out.
downstroke: A fundamental calligraphy stroke where the pen moves from a higher to a lower position with increased pressure, resulting in a thicker line. This stroke can be straight or slightly curved but always maintains its downward direction. Look for the thicker vertical or diagonal lines in letterforms.
pench\u00e9: A variation of arabesque where the dancer bends forward from the hip over the supporting leg, raising the back leg high in the air (above 90 degrees). Creates a dramatic, extreme line. Look for the forward tilt of the body with the extended back leg pointing upward.
slashing: A penalty called when a player swings their stick at an opponent's body or stick in a chopping motion. This aggressive action can lead to injuries and typically results in a minor penalty.
ballonn\u00e9: A jumping step where the working leg extends out at 45 degrees, then the knee bends to bring the foot to a sur le cou-de-pied position (at the ankle). It can be performed as a relevé or as a jump. Look for the extension-bend sequence and the "balloon-like" quality that gives this step its name.
shim sham: A traditional tap dance routine established in the 1930s that has become a recognized sequence in the tap community. The dancer performs a series of steps including heel-toe patterns across several eight-bar choruses. Look for the distinctive lineup formation and synchronized movements. This differs from other routines by its specific step sequence and cultural significance.
toe stand: A balance step where the dancer stands on the tip (toe) of one or both feet. The dancer rises onto the very front edges of the tap shoes, balancing either on one or both feet. Look for the elevated position with only the toe tips contacting the floor. This differs from other balance positions by the extreme forward weight placement.
underhand serve: A serve hit with an upward swing from below shoulder level, often used as a surprise tactic. A controversial serve because it is usually seen as bad sportsmanship. Look for the underarm motion starting below the waist and the ball traveling in an upward arc.
fouett\u00e9: A whipping movement where the working leg whips around from front to side or vice versa. Most famously seen in fouetté turns where the working leg whips around to help generate momentum for multiple turns. Look for the characteristic whipping motion of the leg.
slack trapeze: A trick where the trapeze mount is created using slack (loose) string rather than a direct, taut throw. Visually distinctive as the yo-yo is caught onto the string using a loose, slack loop rather than a straightforward, tight landing. Different from standard trapeze by the visibly loose and looping slack movement.
unnecessary roughness: A penalty for excessively violent or dangerous play. Look for overly aggressive contact after a play is over or clearly dangerous actions like spearing or launching.
stop cut: A specialized technique used to create clean edges and prevent wood splitting. First, a straight cut is made perpendicular to the grain to a predetermined depth (this is the "stop"), then a second angled cut is made that slopes toward the stop cut, removing a wedge of wood. This creates a clean edge at the stop point and is essential for detailing elements like hairlines, hat brims, or other distinct features that require precise boundaries. Visual identification: Look for a perpendicular initial cut followed by an angled secondary cut meeting the first.
beat attack: A preparatory offensive action where the fencer strikes the opponent's blade sharply with their own blade to knock it aside or out of line, creating an opening for an immediate attack. The beat is executed by hitting the middle or "weak" part of the opponent's blade, usually followed by a direct thrust. Look for the distinct sharp contact between blades followed immediately by an attack.
mandala bheda: The ten classical standing positions that serve as the foundation for all Bharatanatyam movements. These are specific ways of placing the feet and distributing body weight to create balanced and aesthetically pleasing postures. Examples include standing with feet together, standing in a wide stance, or positioning the feet in a crossed formation. To identify these positions, look for the deliberate placement of feet in geometric patterns that create stability and visual harmony.
fisherman's knot: A bend consisting of two overhand knots, each tied around the standing part of the other rope. Look for the two simple overhand knots that jam against each other when pulled tight. This knot is commonly used in fishing but is also useful in general rope work for joining lines.
tapotement tapping: Light, rapid, and rhythmic tapping performed with the fingertips, often using alternate hands in quick succession. A form of tapotement (which is... a category of rapid, rhythmic, percussive massage strokes). Look for: therapist quickly and lightly drumming their fingertips alternately on the client's skin surface.
half-flip jump: A jump where skaters rotate from backwards to forwards. Look for only a half rotation, with the skater starting backwards and landing forwards.
side flip: A lateral somersault where the practitioner rotates sideways through the air, similar to a cartwheel but without hand contact. Look for the sideways rotation through the air.
bracket turn: A one-foot turn with a change of edge that results in a "}" shape traced on the ice. Look for the skater turning in the opposite direction of the curve they are skating on.
split stitch: A line stitch created by bringing the needle up through the middle of the previous stitch, splitting the threads to create a textured line. Each new stitch begins by emerging through the middle of the thread of the previous stitch. Look for the characteristic braided or spine-like appearance of the line. This versatile stitch is excellent for outlining, filling areas with texture, and is often used as a foundation for other stitches.
chip shot / lob: A technique where a player uses the front part of their foot to lift the ball over an opponent or goalkeeper (giving the ball a high arc). Look for the subtle, controlled upward motion rather than a powerful strike.
crooked grind: A nosegrind variation (which is grinding on the front truck) where the board is angled diagonally across the obstacle with only the front truck making contact. Look for the angled position with the back truck hanging off the edge.
offstring whip: A 4A (offstring) trick involving the yo-yo tossed freely into the air, completely detached from the string. The player then swiftly throws a loop of slack string around the airborne yo-yo to catch it mid-air. Visually resembles capturing a flying object with a lasso, clearly distinguishing it from attached-string tricks due to the yo-yo’s free-flying nature and the precise catching action.
travel: A violation that occurs when a player takes more than two steps without dribbling the ball, or moves their pivot foot after stopping their dribble. Look for extra steps or pivot foot movement after picking up the dribble.
ceding parry: A defensive technique where the fencer yields to the pressure of the opponent's blade rather than opposing it directly. The defender uses the opponent's pressure to pivot their own blade around to form a new parry position, effectively nullifying the attack by removing the resistance the attacker expected. Look for the defender's blade appearing to give way before redirecting the attack.
berry knot: A decorative lanyard knot used primarily for creating ornamental patterns in rope work. Look for a repeating pattern of knots with a round, berry-like appearance. This is a decorative rather than functional knot, often used in crafts and for aesthetic purposes.
woven wheel rose: A dimensional flower stitch created by weaving the needle under and over spoke-like foundation stitches to form a circular, rose-like shape. First, odd-numbered straight stitches are worked from a center point, then the thread is woven under and over these spokes in a circular motion. Look for the realistic, raised rose or wheel-like appearance. This decorative stitch creates beautiful dimensional flowers in embroidery projects.
faceoff: The method used to start play at the beginning of a period or after a stoppage. Two opposing players square off to compete for possession when an official drops the puck between them onto a designated spot on the ice.
kip up: A transitional move where the dancer goes from lying on their back to standing in one fluid motion by thrusting their legs upward and pushing off their hands/shoulders. Also known as a "spring" in some circles. Look for the explosive movement from back to feet.
vertical mattress suture: An interrupted stitch involving two passes: one deep and wide ("far-far") across the wound, and one shallow and close ("near-near") across the wound in the opposite direction before tying, strongly everting edges (which is turning them outward). Look for: individual stitches showing loops both far from and very close to the wound edge on the surface.
wrap-around pass: A pass where the player wraps their arm around a defender to deliver the ball to a teammate, typically used in the post or when driving to the basket. Look for the passer's arm curving around the defender's body.
dumbbell press: Lying on a bench or sitting upright, pushing dumbbells upwards from chest or shoulder level until the arms are fully extended overhead or above the chest, then lowering the weights back down. Look for: a person pushing dumbbells away from their torso (either upwards from the chest on a bench, or vertically from the shoulders while seated/standing).
kartari adavu: A movement characterized by scissor-like actions of both arms and legs. The name "Kartari" refers to scissors in Sanskrit. The dancer crosses and separates the arms in a cutting motion while the feet perform matching patterns. The hands typically form specific gestures that enhance the scissor-like appearance. To identify this movement, look for the distinctive crossing and opening of arms coordinated with precise foot patterns, creating a visual representation of scissors in motion.
toe hook: A technique where a climber uses the top of their foot (toes pointing toward body) to hook onto a hold or feature, pulling with the foot to maintain body tension and prevent swinging. This creates an additional point of contact that works like another hand. Look for a climber hooking the top of their shoe over a hold.
hesitation / hesi: A dribbling move where the player briefly slows down or pauses their dribble to make the defender think they're stopping, then quickly accelerates past them. Look for the momentary slowing followed by a burst of speed.
handling the ball: A method of dismissal where the batsman deliberately touches the ball with a hand not holding the bat. Look for the batsman using his hand to prevent the ball from hitting the stumps or to assist fielding.
unsportsmanlike conduct: A penalty for behavior that is considered contrary to the spirit of fair play. Look for taunting, excessive celebrations, removing the helmet on the field, or other demonstrative behavior.
riffle: A three-sound step combining a toe tap, dig, and spank (backward brush). The dancer taps the toe, digs it into the floor, then brushes backward with the ball of the foot. Look for the quick three-sound sequence initiated with the toe. This differs from a riff by including the toe tap at the beginning.
tic tac: A wall technique where the practitioner takes a step off a wall to gain height or change direction, similar to a rebound. Look for the quick foot plant and push off the wall.
switch hit: An unorthodox batting shot where the batsman changes his stance from right to left-handed (or vice versa) just before the ball is delivered. Look for the complete reversal of grip and stance as the bowler delivers.
\u00e9chapp\u00e9: A movement where the feet move from a closed position (first or fifth) to an open position (second or fourth) with a jump or relevé in between. The term means "escaped." Look for the opening of the feet from close together to separated positions.
buttonhole stitch: A stitch that creates a firm edge with a series of knots along one side, traditionally used to reinforce buttonholes but also popular as a decorative stitch for borders and edgings. The stitch is worked by making a series of loops along the edge of fabric, with the thread forming a knot at the base of each loop. Look for the characteristic ridge of thread along one side with even loops extending from it. This versatile stitch can be worked closely together or spaced apart for different decorative effects.
atonic seizure: A short seizure episode featuring an abrupt and complete loss of muscle tone, causing body muscles to instantly become limp and unresponsive. This sudden loss of muscle control can cause head dropping forward, dropping held objects, or an unexpected collapse or fall to the ground. Such episodes last only a few seconds, yet the risk of injury from falls makes protective measures, such as helmets, especially recommended in affected children or anyone with frequent atonic seizures.
shoulder press / overhead press: Standing or sitting, pushing a barbell or dumbbells vertically upward from shoulder height until arms are fully extended overhead, then lowering the weight back to shoulder level under control. Look for: a person pushing weights straight up overhead from their shoulders.
buffalo: A combination step consisting of a leap, shuffle, and another step with the crossing foot. The dancer leaps onto one foot while crossing the other foot in front, performs a shuffle with the crossed foot, then steps on that same foot. Look for the distinct cross-over position and the foot remaining crossed throughout. This differs from other shuffle steps by the crossed position of the feet.
breakaway: A foundational sidestyle throw where the yo-yo is launched sideways across the body, typically setting up horizontal tricks like Trapeze. Visually appears as a horizontal arc thrown outward to the side. Differs from a downward throw (Throw Down) by its horizontal direction.
double dribble: A violation that occurs when a player stops dribbling the ball and then starts dribbling again, or dribbles with both hands simultaneously. Look for the referee's whistle after a player picks up their dribble and starts again.
glissade: A traveling step that serves as a linking movement between other steps. The dancer slides the working foot from fifth position in the desired direction, then closes the other foot to it. The name means "glide." Look for the smooth, gliding quality as the feet slide along the floor.
cupie: Also called "awesome," this is a variation of an extension stunt where the flyer stands with both feet together in one hand of a single base or the hands of multiple bases held close together. Look for the flyer's feet positioned very close together in the base's hands above their head.
electric fan: A horizontal trick (5A) where the yo-yo and counterweight continuously spin horizontally, resembling helicopter blades. Visually clear as both yo-yo and weight rotate rapidly around the player's hand horizontally. Distinct from vertical tricks due to its horizontal orientation.
trucker's hitch: A compound knot system used to create mechanical advantage when tensioning a rope, particularly for securing loads. Look for the pulley-like loop with a second hitch to lock the tension. This effective system allows for significant tension to be applied and maintained.
boston mess: A columns variation of Mills Mess where the balls move in three vertical columns while the arms perform crossing and uncrossing movements. The juggler's hands switch which balls they're throwing without changing the overall column pattern. Look for three vertical ball paths with arms crossing underneath each other.
graded wash: A wash technique that creates a smooth transition from dark to light value or from one color to another. Unlike a flat wash, a graded wash begins with a more concentrated pigment mixture, then gradually becomes more diluted with water as the wash progresses, creating a smooth gradient effect. Graded washes are ideal for depicting skies, shadows, or any area requiring a smooth tonal transition. Look for the seamless gradation from dark to light or between colors.
back stitch: A strong, durable hand sewing stitch where each new stitch overlaps with the previous one, creating a continuous line of thread on the fabric's surface. The needle doubles back on itself with each stitch, eliminating the spaces seen in running stitches and creating a sturdy seam that resembles machine stitching. Look for a solid line of thread on the front and a series of overlapping stitches on the back.
bat hang: A specialized inverted position where a climber hangs upside down from a hold or feature, typically by hooking both toes over the hold while facing away from the wall. This technique allows climbers to rest or make transitions while using primarily leg strength. Look for a climber hanging completely upside down using their feet rather than their hands.
press and push: A bread-making folding technique where the dough is pressed flat and then pushed away with the heel of the hand to develop gluten. This motion stretches the dough and creates strength without excessive kneading. Look for the flattening and pushing motion that extends the dough outward.
rinsing the filter: The process of wetting a paper filter with hot water before adding coffee grounds. This removes paper taste, preheats the brewing equipment, and helps the filter adhere properly to the brewing device. Look for the barista pouring hot water through the empty filter and discarding this water before adding coffee.
punt: A kick performed by dropping the ball and kicking it before it hits the ground, typically on fourth down. Look for a specialist (punter) catching the snap and kicking the ball before it touches the ground.
basket toss: A stunt where three or four bases throw the flyer into the air by interlocking their hands to form a "basket" shape. The flyer performs a skill in the air before being caught in a cradle position. Look for the initial basket grip formation and the high vertical toss with aerial skills performed.
cat balance: A precision movement (which is careful and controlled) where the practitioner maintains balance on a narrow surface, typically in a crouched position resembling a cat. Look for the low, balanced stance on narrow objects.
on drive: A front-foot batting shot played to a full delivery on or outside leg stump, with the batsman driving the ball through the on side. Look for the forward stride and straight bat swing aimed toward the mid-on region.
periya adavu: A "grand" movement characterized by expansive, sweeping actions of both arms and legs. "Periya" means "big" or "large" in Tamil. The dancer uses extended arm gestures and wide leg movements that cover significant space, creating a majestic quality. To identify this movement, look for the expansive nature of the movements - arms reached to their fullest extension and legs covering maximum floor space, creating an impression of grandeur.
steal: A defensive action where a player legally takes the ball away from an opponent who has possession, causing a turnover. Look for the defender gaining possession of the ball from the offense without a shot attempt.
blooming: The initial stage of brewing pour-over coffee where a small amount of hot water is added to freshly ground coffee. This causes the coffee to release carbon dioxide gas, creating a bubbling or swelling effect that improves extraction by allowing water to better access the flavor compounds. Look for the coffee grounds expanding and bubbling when the water is first added, followed by a waiting period before continuing to pour.
lazy vault: A sideways vault technique used for diagonal approaches where the practitioner passes over an obstacle with their legs to one side. Look for the sideways entry and exit with minimal upward motion.
rocker: A one-foot turn where the skater changes from back to front or front to back, maintaining the same edge (outside to outside or inside to inside). The blade turns in the direction of the exit curve.
cow hitch: A simple hitch used to attach a rope to a pole, ring, or similar object. Also known as the Lark's Head, it's formed by making a loop, placing it around the object, then passing both ends through the loop and pulling tight. Look for the simple symmetrical loop around the object with both ends emerging in the same direction. This is a quick but relatively insecure knot.
boiling: A cooking method where food is immersed in water or liquid that has reached its boiling point (100°C/212°F), characterized by large, vigorous bubbles breaking at the surface. This high-heat method is suitable for pasta and some vegetables but can make meat tough. Look for rapidly bubbling water with food fully submerged.
reverse vault: A 360-degree rotational vault where the practitioner places one hand on the obstacle and spins around it. Look for the complete circular rotation around the obstacle.
sous vide: A precise cooking technique where food is sealed in a vacuum or airtight bag and cooked in temperature-controlled water for extended periods. This method ensures even cooking and precise doneness throughout the food. Look for the vacuum-sealed food immersed in water maintained at an exact temperature.
off spin: A spinning delivery where the ball turns from off to leg for a right-handed batsman. Look for the bowler using finger-spin with an action that has the palm facing the batsman at release.
pirouette: A complete turn of the body on one foot, with the other foot typically in passé (at the knee). Can be performed en dehors (turning outward) or en dedans (turning inward). Look for the centered spinning motion on a single leg with the body aligned over the supporting foot.
pas de bourr\u00e9e: A quick, running step consisting of three small steps that alternate feet, typically performed on the balls of the feet. Often used as a connecting step between more significant movements. Look for the three small, quick steps with alternating feet.
herkie jump: A cheerleading jump named after Lawrence "Herkie" Herkimer where one leg extends straight to the side while the other bends toward the ground, creating an asymmetrical position. Look for the straight leg to one side and the bent knee pointing down.
simmering: A gentle cooking method where liquid is heated to just below the boiling point (185-205°F/85-96°C), producing small bubbles that steadily rise to the surface. This slow, moist-heat method is ideal for stocks, soups, and tenderizing foods. Look for the gentle, continuous bubbling.
scoring: The technique of making shallow cuts on the surface of bread dough or meat before cooking. For bread, this controls how the loaf expands during baking; for meat, it helps tenderize and allows marinades to penetrate. Look for the deliberate patterns of cuts on the surface.
pad stack save: A save technique where the goaltender drops to one side and stacks both leg pads horizontally to create a wall-like barrier. This desperate save is used when the goalie must cover a large portion of the net quickly.
color packing: The technique of depositing tattoo ink into the skin to create solid, fully saturated areas of color with no transparency or skin showing through. This often involves moving the needle grouping (which is... the configuration of needles used, often larger flat groups called magnums or round shaders for packing) in small, tight circles or consistent back-and-forth motions to ensure even ink deposit. Look for: the artist repeatedly going over a specific area with the tattoo machine, using overlapping circular or scrubbing motions, resulting in a patch of dense, opaque color.
squash shot: A defensive shot hit while stretching or from behind the body position, often with slice. Shot typically hit on the run from a defensive position, either with slice, or from behind the player's stance. Look for the stretched-out position and defensive nature of the shot.
one-handed backhand: A backhand stroke executed with only one hand on the racquet, allowing for reach and variety in shot selection. Look for the player using their non-dominant arm extended away from their body while their dominant hand holds the racquet.
no hands: Also called "Chin Chin" or "Cry Baby," this is a stunt position where the flyer places their foot under their chin without using hands for support. Look for the foot positioned directly under the chin with no hand assistance.
warped sonic: A sonic variant that begins with a charge (conical spin in place) followed by a pass motion (0.5 rotation transfer), creating a modified transfer between slots. The pen charges first, then passes to the next position. Look for the initial charging spin before the transfer movement. This differs from regular sonic by incorporating the charge motion before the transfer.
bris\u00e9: A small, beaten jump where the working leg brushes into the air while the dancer pushes off the floor with the supporting leg. The legs beat together in the air before landing. The term means "broken" and refers to the broken or sharp quality of the movement. Look for the quick beating action of the legs in mid-air.
webster: A front flip variation performed from one leg, where the practitioner kicks the back leg up to initiate the forward rotation. Look for the single-leg takeoff and forward flip.
toe touch jump: One of the most recognized cheerleading jumps where the athlete jumps and spreads their legs out to the sides in a straddle position while reaching their arms toward their toes in a T position. Look for the wide split position with pointed toes and arms extending outward.
jigger: A bartending measuring tool with an hourglass shape featuring two different-sized measuring cups (typically 1 oz/1.5 oz or other standard measurements). The bartender uses this precision instrument to accurately measure ingredients for cocktails, ensuring consistency in taste and alcohol content across drinks.
velvet rolls: A smooth and symmetrical two-handed 3A trick in which both yo-yos roll simultaneously in parallel, coordinated loops around the strings. Visually elegant, as both yo-yos move harmoniously in matching circular or rolling patterns, like synchronized swimmers performing side-by-side somersaults. Clearly distinct from alternating patterns (like Bluelien Rolls) by their simultaneous, mirrored movements.
tasting: The act of sampling food during the cooking process to assess and adjust flavor, seasoning, texture, and doneness before serving. Regular tasting allows the cook to make necessary adjustments to salt, spices, acidity, or cooking time to achieve the desired result. Look for the practice of sampling small amounts of food with a clean utensil throughout preparation to guide seasoning decisions.
leg press: Sitting in a leg press machine with feet placed shoulder-width apart on a platform, pushing the platform away from the body (on sled-type machines) or pushing the seat away from the platform (on lever-type machines) by extending the knees and hips, then controlling the weight back by bending the knees. Look for: a person sitting in a machine and pushing a weighted platform with their feet.
chops: A pattern based on the cascade that incorporates semicircular carrying movements with one or both hands. After catching a ball, the juggler carries it in a downward-pointing semicircle over another ball or hand before tossing it up. Look for the distinctive semicircular carrying motion before throws.
chevron stitch: A decorative embroidery stitch that creates a zigzag pattern resembling the chevron symbol (∧∧∧). Made by working slanted stitches in alternating directions, forming a series of connected V-shapes. Look for a regular zigzag pattern with balanced, even points that create a dynamic linear design, often used for borders or embellishment.
mankading (running out the non-striker): A method of dismissal where the bowler runs out the non-striking batsman who leaves his crease before the ball is delivered. Look for the bowler removing the bails at the non-striker's end during the delivery stride.
figure-of-eight suture: An interrupted stitch where the needle passes through tissue in a pattern resembling an "8" or "X", crossing over itself before being tied, often used to stop bleeding or close small holes. Look for: a single tied stitch that clearly forms an "X" shape on the tissue surface.
goal kick: A set piece (stopped play restart) awarded when the ball crosses the goal line after last touching an attacking player. Look for the goalkeeper or defender placing the ball in the 6-yard box before kicking.
stop hit: A counterattack that lands against the opponent's attack by taking advantage of a moment of hesitation, poor execution, or by precisely timing the action. In foil and sabre, a stop hit must clearly arrive at least one fencing tempo before the original attack to be awarded the point. Look for the counterattack that intercepts the opponent's developing attack
dip: Supporting the body on parallel bars or the edge of a bench with arms straight, lowering the torso by bending the elbows (usually keeping them tucked back), then pushing back up to the starting position by straightening the arms. Look for: a person lowering and raising their body between parallel bars or off a bench edge using arm strength.
illegal batting: A penalty where a player deliberately strikes or bats a loose ball with their hand or arm. Look for a player intentionally swatting at a loose ball rather than trying to recover it.
double flip: A flip jump with two rotations in the air. Look for the inside edge takeoff with toe pick assistance.
water knot: A knot used to join two ends of flat webbing or strapping, commonly used in climbing and rigging. Look for the overhand knot tied in one end with the other end following the same path in reverse. This secure knot is essential for joining flat materials where regular rope knots would be unsuitable.
constrictor knot: A binding knot that is exceptionally secure and tightens under strain. Similar to a clove hitch, but with one end passed under the other to form an overhand knot beneath a riding turn. Look for the exceptional tightness and grip on the object it binds. This knot is so secure it often must be cut to be removed after being tightened, making it excellent for temporary whipping or securing objects.
reverse cascade: A pattern where all throws are "overthrows" that go over the other balls rather than under them as in the standard cascade. The balls follow the cascade pattern but with the throwing directions reversed. Look for all balls traveling over the top of the pattern rather than underneath.
slider: A delivery bowled by a leg-spinner that skids on after pitching, with less turn than expected. Look for the ball traveling straighter and faster than the bowler's normal leg-break delivery.
thread the needle: A footwork move where the dancer passes one leg through the opening created by their supporting arm and other leg, creating a "threading" motion. Look for the distinctive weaving movement of the leg through the space created by the arm and other leg.
noseslide: A slide trick where the skater ollie's (jumps with the board) onto an obstacle and slides with the nose (front end of the board) on the edge or rail. Look for the front portion of the deck making contact while the tail is elevated.
windmill: A foundational 5A (counterweight/freehand) trick characterized by the yo-yo and the attached counterweight simultaneously swinging in continuous, large vertical circles around the player’s hand. Visually noticeable as the hand forms the central pivot, with the yo-yo and weight circling in a large, vertical, windmill-like pattern. Distinguished from horizontal tricks (like Electric Fan) by its larger, vertical circular plane.
iron whip: One-handed trick involving rapidly whipping slack string around the yo-yo from behind. Visually rapid and sharp, distinguished from Jade Whip by direction (from behind rather than front).
441: A juggling pattern where each ball is thrown and caught by the same hand, with a horizontal pass performed every two throws. This creates a "half-box" shape in the air, with vertical throws followed by horizontal passes. Look for the alternating vertical throws and horizontal passes between hands.
standing double crochet: A technique that allows you to start a new row or round with a double crochet stitch without using beginning chains. You begin by wrapping the yarn twice around your hook before inserting into the specified stitch, then complete the double crochet as normal. This creates a cleaner, more professional-looking start than the traditional chain-3 beginning, especially for color changes. Standing double crochet eliminates the visible chains at the beginning of rows and blends seamlessly with other double crochet stitches in your project.
nattadavu 5: A complex stretching movement that incorporates diagonal patterns with the legs.
