Look for the distinctive raised squares separated by indented lines, creating a waffle-like appearance.
elbow track: A power move similar to a windmill but performed with the body weight supported on the elbows instead of the shoulders or upper back. The elbows "track" along the floor during rotation. Look for the circular body movement with elbow support.
purging steam wand: The process of releasing steam through the steam wand before and after steaming milk. This cleans the wand by removing condensed water before use and milk residue after use, ensuring hygiene and optimal performance. Look for the barista briefly turning on the steam while pointing the wand into a cloth or drip tray, producing a short burst of steam.
figure 8: A trick where the pen traces a figure-8 pattern through combined spin and movement techniques. The pen typically moves between two points while rotating, creating the distinctive 8 shape in the air. Look for the pen drawing an hourglass-like pattern. This differs from infinity by the specific figure-8 shape rather than a continuous loop symbol.
stippling: A technique where paint is applied using small dots or short strokes rather than continuous brush strokes. These dots can be applied with the tip of a brush, pen, or other pointed tool to build up areas of color and create texture. Stippling is particularly effective for rendering texture in foliage, creating gradual transitions, or depicting rough surfaces. Look for the distinctive pattern of small dots or marks that collectively create areas of color and texture.
thinning (with thinning shears): Using scissors with notched blades (teeth on one or both blades) to cut a portion of the hair within a section, removing bulk and adding texture without significantly reducing the overall length. Look for: scissors with visible teeth closing on a hair section, removing some strands while leaving others intact.
orthostatic tremor: An uncommon condition involving rapid muscle shaking in the legs, triggered primarily when standing still, making standing uncomfortable and difficult. The tremor stops or diminishes significantly when sitting, walking, or leaning against something. Before diagnosis, people experiencing orthostatic tremor often describe a sense of unsteady leg vibration during quiet standing positions.
chest pass: A basic two-handed pass made from the chest of the passer to the chest of the receiver without the ball touching the floor. Look for the straight-line movement of the ball from one player to another.
cricket: A power move where the dancer begins in a turtle freeze position and hops while rotating their body in a circular motion, using their hands to push off the ground. Look for the distinctive hopping rotation from the supported position.
razor cutting: Using a straight-edge or guarded razor tool to slice through hair sections, often creating softer, more textured ends compared to scissors. Look for: a razor tool (not scissors) sliding through the hair, often at an angle, to cut it.
bolasie flick: A skill move where a player rolls the ball up the back of their standing leg with their other foot, then flicks it over their head (and the defender). Look for the distinctive rolling motion followed by the high flick over the head.
two-handed backhand: A backhand stroke hit with both hands on the racquet grip, providing more power and stability. Backhand stroke hit with both hands on the grip. Look for both hands gripping the racquet during the entire swing.
glove save: A save where the goaltender catches and secures the puck using the special catching glove worn on their non-stick hand. A properly executed glove save completely stops play by preventing rebounds.
nattadavu 7: A stretching movement that incorporates turning elements. The dancer lifts one leg, places the heel to the side, then turns the entire body while maintaining balance, creating a spiraling movement quality. This requires significant control and coordination as the dancer must maintain balance while rotating the body. To identify this movement, look for the distinctive turning action that occurs during the leg extension, creating a spiral effect.
variegated wash: A wash technique where multiple colors are applied within the same wet area, allowing them to blend and interact naturally. Unlike a flat or graded wash, a variegated wash deliberately incorporates color changes across the surface. This technique creates dynamic, blended effects where colors flow together at their boundaries. Variegated washes are ideal for skies, backgrounds, or any area requiring subtle color transitions. Look for the distinctive flowing blend of multiple colors within a single wash area.
rubaud method: A gentle hand-mixing technique for bread dough named after baker Gérard Rubaud. It involves repeatedly scooping the dough from the bottom of the bowl with a cupped hand and letting it fall back, mimicking the action of a professional diving-arm mixer. Look for the repetitive scooping motion that gradually strengthens the dough without overworking it.
moss stitch: Also known as the granite or linen stitch, this pattern alternates single crochet and chain stitches with each row offset. This creates a woven-looking texture with a dense but flexible fabric. Look for the tight, woven appearance with small spaces that create a subtle texture.
bayamo: A Cuban salsa figure where the lead directs the follow behind their back with both hands held high overhead. The move gets its name because the lead must keep both hands high over their head as the follow is led behind their back. Look for the characteristic high hand position and the follow moving behind the lead's back.
half-volley: A shot made immediately after the ball bounces, striking it on the rise very close to the ground. The racquet contacts the ball almost at surface level. Look for the player hitting the ball almost simultaneously with its bounce, with minimal backswing.
walk the dog: A classic, visually charming trick in which the spinning yo-yo, after being thrown downward (Sleeper), is gently placed onto the ground and allowed to roll forward, simulating the motion of walking a dog on a leash. Easily recognizable visually due to the rolling yo-yo on the floor surface. Differentiated from aerial or string-based tricks by the distinct interaction with the floor.
pyramid: A structure formed when two or more stunts are connected, often with flyers at different levels supporting each other. Look for multiple stunt groups linked together to create a larger structure with various heights and positions.
spike stitch: A technique where you insert your hook into a stitch from a previous row (one or more rows below the current working row) rather than the row immediately before. The stitch is worked normally but appears elongated as it "spikes" down into the fabric. This creates vertical lines and texture in your work and is excellent for adding color patterns without carrying yarn across rows. Spike stitches need to be worked with enough slack to prevent pulling the fabric, and they're often used in combination with regular stitches for decorative effects.
backheel: A technique where a player kicks the ball behind them using the heel of their foot (the back part of the foot) instead of the instep or toes. Look for the distinctive backward motion of the foot to strike the ball.
channel cutting: A texturizing technique (which is... removing bulk or creating varied lengths within a section) where shears cut along the length of a hair section, carving out 'channels' to remove hair from the interior, not just the ends. Look for: scissors moving parallel or angled along the hair shaft, cutting hair within the section's length.
manual: A balance trick where the skater rides on just the back wheels with the front wheels lifted off the ground while rolling forward (similar to a wheelie on a bicycle). Look for the front of the skateboard lifted up and the skater maintaining balance on just the back wheels.
finger roll layup: A specialized layup where the shooter rolls the ball off their fingertips with a high arc to avoid shot blockers. Look for the gentle, rolling motion of the ball as it leaves the shooter's hand.
shooting foul: A personal foul committed against a player in the act of shooting, resulting in free throws. Look for contact with the shooter while the ball is still in their hands during a shot attempt.
docking: The process of making small holes in raw dough or pastry before baking, typically using a fork or special docking tool. This prevents the dough from bubbling, puffing up, or rising unevenly during baking. Look for the pattern of small holes or perforations in the unbaked dough.
kickflip: A trick where the skater performs an ollie (jumping with the board) while flicking the front foot off the side of the board to make it rotate along its long axis (making the board flip or spin like a rolling pin). Look for the board spinning completely around its length axis before the skater lands.
index bak (korean bak): A backaround (fingerless around with diagonal motion) performed specifically around the index finger, featuring a slanted spinning path initiated by hand rotation rather than finger push. Look for the pen rotating around the index finger following a diagonal trajectory without direct finger contact. This differs from index around by using diagonal motion and no finger propulsion.
embo\u00eet\u00e9: A step characterized by crossing one foot in front of or behind the other, with legs bent. Often performed as a series of small, precise transfers of weight under the body line. Look for the alternating passing of the feet while the dancer remains on pointe or demi-pointe.
cretan stitch: A decorative embroidery stitch forming open loops in a zigzag pattern with diagonal stitches slanting in alternating directions. The stitch creates a series of open V-shapes along a central line, resembling a more open herringbone pattern. Look for a line of open V-shapes that follow a central path, often used in crewel embroidery for filling or outline work.
grinding: The process of breaking whole coffee beans into smaller particles suitable for brewing. The size of the grind affects extraction and varies based on brewing method, with espresso requiring a fine grind and pour-over methods using medium to coarse grinds. Look for coffee beans being processed through a mechanical grinder, resulting in small particles ready for brewing.
run out: A method of dismissal where the batsman is out of his ground when the stumps are broken by the ball. Look for the fielder throwing down the stumps while the batsman is attempting a run between wickets.
sweep: A running play where the ball carrier runs laterally toward the sideline before turning upfield. Look for a running back receiving the ball and immediately running parallel to the line of scrimmage toward the outside.
ladder stitch: A stitch used to create an invisible join between two pieces of fabric or to close an opening. The stitch weaves back and forth between the folded edges of fabric, creating a ladder-like structure that pulls together when the thread is tightened. Look for the zigzag pattern of thread that disappears when pulled tight. This utility stitch is essential for closing stuffed items, attaching appliqués, or making invisible seams.
thattadavu 2: A foot-tapping pattern that introduces double taps. Building on Thattadavu 1, this variation has the dancer tap each foot twice before alternating to the other foot. The rhythm changes to accommodate this double-tapping pattern, creating a different musical effect. To identify this movement, look for the double-tapping action on each foot before switching sides.     (For context, here is a definition for Thattadavu 1: the most basic foot-tapping movement in Bharatanatyam. 'Thatta' means 'to tap' in Tamil. The dancer stands in a half-sitting position with bent knees and flat feet, then alternately taps the right and left foot on the ground, creating rhythmic sounds without using hand gestures. To identify this movement, look for the simple alternating foot taps performed with the dancer maintaining a stable, bent-knee position.)
standing back tuck: A tumbling skill where the athlete performs a backward flip from a standing position, tucking their knees to their chest for rotation. Look for the vertical jump followed by the tucked flip with no forward momentum.
overturn: A "hill-shaped" stroke that begins with a thin upward line, curves at the top, and transitions into a thick downward line. The stroke creates a smooth transition from thin to thick as it changes direction from upward to downward. Look for the n-shaped formation with thickness variation in the downward portion.
double crochet: A basic tall stitch formed by yarning over once before inserting the hook into the stitch, then pulling up a loop and completing by drawing yarn through two loops at a time twice. This creates a stitch that is approximately twice the height of a single crochet. Look for the taller stitch with a distinctive "post" section.
bulgarian split squat: Standing with the top of one foot resting on an elevated surface (like a bench) behind the body, lowering the hips by bending the front knee until the front thigh is near parallel to the ground, keeping the torso upright, then pushing back up through the front foot. Look for: a person squatting on one leg with the back foot raised on a bench or platform.
heel-to-shin test: Assessing lower limb coordination, usually performed lying down, where the person places the heel of one foot onto the knee of the opposite leg and then slides it smoothly down the shin towards the ankle. Look for: the person sliding their heel down the shin of the other leg; observe for smoothness, accuracy (staying on the shin), and control.
scoring and slipping: A joining technique used to attach separate pieces of clay. The surfaces to be joined are first "scored" (scratched with lines or crosshatches using a tool) and then "slipped" (coated with a creamy mixture of clay and water). When pressed together, these prepared surfaces create a strong bond. Look for the characteristic scratch marks before joining and the smoothed connection points after.
american twist serve: A serve hit with a combination of slice (sidespin) and topspin that causes the ball to curve in one direction then kick in the opposite direction after bouncing. Look for the distinctive curve and high bounce that makes the ball kick away from the receiver.
fadeaway: A jump shot where the shooter leans or jumps away from the basket while shooting to create space between themselves and the defender. Look for the backward body motion while releasing the shot.
stumping: A method of dismissal where the wicketkeeper removes the bails when the batsman is out of his crease and not attempting a run. Look for the batsman stepping out to play a shot, missing, and the wicketkeeper quickly removing the bails.
waddling gait: A distinctive walking pattern marked by exaggerated side-to-side swaying or tilting of the hips and trunk with each step, often due to weakness in the hip abductor muscles (which are muscles that move the leg away from the body's midline). The body leans towards the weight-bearing leg to lift the swinging leg clear of the ground. Look for: a person walking with a noticeable side-to-side rocking motion of their upper body and hips, sometimes resembling the walk of a duck; shoulders may dip significantly side-to-side.
8-second violation: A rule violation that occurs when the offensive team fails to advance the ball from their backcourt (defensive half of the court) to the frontcourt (offensive half) within 8 seconds after gaining possession. Look for the referee's signal showing the violation when the time limit expires.
scarify seeds: Intentionally damaging the hard outer coating of seeds before planting, using methods like nicking with a knife, rubbing with sandpaper, or soaking, to help germination (which is... the seed sprouting). Look for: a person physically altering hard seeds using tools like sandpaper or clippers, or soaking them.
one-two pass: A quick combination play where a player passes to a teammate and immediately receives a return pass to bypass a defender. Look for the quick exchange of passes between two players.
foot tapping: Assessing lower limb coordination and speed by having the person tap their foot (usually the ball of the foot, keeping the heel on the ground) as quickly and rhythmically as possible. Look for: the person rapidly tapping their foot on the floor; note the speed, rhythm, and consistency of the movement.
inside hook: A skill move where a player uses the inside of their foot to quickly change direction of the ball (hooking it away from a defender). Look for the movement where the player pulls the ball across their body with the inside of the foot.
air chair: A freeze position where the dancer balances on one hand with the opposite elbow stabbed into the lower back/hip area and both legs extended outward. The dancer's body is held horizontally parallel to the ground. Look for the characteristic one-arm support with the body held parallel to the floor.
tapping: A distribution technique where the barista lightly taps the portafilter to settle ground coffee before tamping. Look for gentle tapping motions against the countertop or palm that cause the coffee grounds to settle into a level bed in the portafilter basket.
deglazing: The technique of adding liquid (wine, stock, or other flavorful liquids) to a hot pan after cooking meat or vegetables to dissolve the caramelized bits (fond) stuck to the bottom. This creates the base for flavorful sauces and gravies. Look for the scraping motion and the liquid turning brown as it incorporates the fond.
kong vault: A fundamental parkour vault where the practitioner dives forward over an obstacle, placing both hands down and passing their legs between their arms. Look for the characteristic diving motion with hands placed on the obstacle.
appel: A sharp stamping of the front foot against the ground to produce a sound that distracts or startles the opponent. It can be executed either during an advance or directly from the en garde position, and may precede a lunge or serve merely as a distraction. Some fencers also use an appel with the rear foot to halt a bout. Look for the distinct stomping sound and the momentary pause that often follows.
frontside flip: A combination trick where the skater performs a kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis) while rotating their body and board 180 degrees frontside (rotation where the skater's chest faces the direction of travel). Look for the simultaneous rotation and flip with the skater's chest facing the direction of travel.
ischemic compression: Applying direct, static (unmoving) pressure with a thumb, finger, or elbow to a specific tender or tight spot (often called a trigger point, which is... a hyperirritable spot in a muscle), holding the pressure until the muscle tension or referred sensation diminishes. Look for: therapist pressing firmly into one small point and holding that pressure steadily without movement for several seconds or longer.
double clutch: A dynamic movement where a climber grabs an intermediate hold briefly before immediately releasing it to grab the target hold, using the intermediate hold to extend their reach. This allows accessing distant holds that couldn't be reached with a single movement. Look for a climber touching one hold momentarily before quickly moving to another.
gaston: A grip technique where the climber presses outward with their hand on a vertical hold, thumb pointing down and elbow pointing away from the body (opposite of a sidepull). The pressure is directed outward rather than pulling inward, using shoulder strength for stability. Look for a hand position similar to opening an elevator door.
nollie: An ollie (jumping with the board) performed by popping the nose of the board instead of the tail (jumping using the front of the board). Look for the ollie motion performed at the front of the board.
reverse sweep: An unorthodox batting shot where the batsman switches his hands on the bat handle to sweep the ball in the opposite direction to a conventional sweep. Look for the reversed grip and the batsman sweeping toward the third man region.
illegal forward pass: A penalty where a forward pass is thrown from beyond the line of scrimmage or when a second forward pass is thrown on the same play. Look for a quarterback clearly beyond the line of scrimmage when throwing or a second forward pass occurring after a completed pass.
double fisherman's knot: A bend consisting of two interlocking barrel knots (double overhand knots), each tied around the standing part of the other rope. Look for the symmetrical appearance with two barrel-shaped sections pressed against each other. This is an exceptionally secure knot for joining two ropes, especially popular in climbing where security is critical.
flunge: A combination of a lunge and flèche attack unique to saber. This technique evolved after rule changes in 1992 prohibited running attacks in saber. The fencer lunges while simultaneously driving forward beyond the normal lunge distance, but without the characteristic running aspect of a flèche. Look for the aggressive forward motion that extends beyond a standard lunge but stops short of a running action.
nest: A flair bartending move where a bottle is caught inside a shaker tin or another container. The bartender positions the receiving vessel to perfectly intercept the falling bottle, with the bottle typically landing with its bottom inside the container, creating a satisfying visual and auditory effect as the objects connect.
pullback: A step where the dancer pushes off the floor and slides the feet backward. The dancer jumps slightly while pulling both feet backward with ball taps, then lands. Look for the distinctive backward sliding movement with the feet staying close to the floor. This differs from other backward steps by the sliding action and slight elevation.
advance lunge / marche fente: A combined forward movement where the fencer first takes a step forward (advance/marche) followed immediately by a lunge (fente). This extends the reach of a standard lunge and is executed in one continuous motion with the arm extending before or during the advance, but always before the lunge. Look for the fencer taking a step forward with the front foot and immediately pushing off the back leg for the lunge.
dysdiadochokinesia: Assessing the ability to perform rapid alternating movements, like quickly flipping hands palm-up/palm-down on thighs. Impairment (dysdiadochokinesia itself) manifests as slow, clumsy, or irregular movements, indicating issues with coordination, often related to the cerebellum (which is a part of the brain coordinating movement). Look for: a person attempting rapid hand flipping or finger/foot tapping; observe for slowness, irregularity, or clumsiness instead of smooth, fast, rhythmic motion.
roulette turn / marseille turn: A skill move where a player uses the sole of one foot to roll the ball, pivots 360 degrees around it, and exits with the ball using the other foot. Look for the spinning motion around the ball.
hop the fence: Looping trick (2A) characterized by vertical loops forward, visually like yo-yo hopping over an imaginary fence repeatedly. Distinct from horizontal loops due to vertical plane.
la croqueta: A skill move where a player quickly shifts the ball from one foot to the other to move past a defender (a subtle side-to-side movement). Look for the quick transfer of the ball between feet while moving forward.
6-step: A fundamental footwork pattern where the dancer moves in a circular motion on the floor using six distinct steps. The dancer supports their body weight with their hands while their legs create a circular walking pattern. Look for the dancer's feet moving in a complete circular sequence while maintaining hand support.
hammer curl: Standing or sitting, holding dumbbells with palms facing each other (neutral grip, like holding a hammer), curling the weights up towards the shoulders by bending the elbows, keeping palms facing inwards throughout the movement, then lowering back down. Look for: a person curling dumbbells with palms facing their body.
blocker save: A save where the goaltender uses the rectangular pad worn on their stick hand (called the blocker) to deflect an incoming shot away from the goal. The blocker is designed to redirect pucks to the corners or away from dangerous areas.
coule (glide): An offensive action where the fencer extends their sword arm and slides lightly down the opponent's blade while maintaining contact throughout the movement. This technique uses the opponent's blade as a guide to the target while applying gentle pressure to control it. Look for the continuous contact between blades as the attacker's point moves toward the target.
josephine knot: A decorative knot that creates an attractive pattern resembling interlinked rings. Look for the interwoven loops that create a symmetrical, ornamental appearance. This knot is primarily used for decorative purposes rather than functional applications.
paddle and roll: A step combining a dig and brush (the paddle) followed by a ball and heel (the roll). The dancer digs the toe, brushes backward, steps on the ball of the foot, and drops the heel in a smooth motion. Look for the four distinct sounds in a flowing sequence. This differs from the paradiddle only in terminology, as they're essentially the same step.
charge: A fundamental technique where the pen spins continuously in a conical pattern (like an inverted cone or funnel) within a single finger slot (the space between two fingers). The pen rotates in place without changing position, spinning clockwise in the right hand and counterclockwise in the left hand when viewed from above. Look for the pen spinning in one location with a cone-shaped rotation path. This differs from other spinning tricks because the pen stays in one spot rather than traveling between fingers or around them.
steaming: A moist-heat cooking method where food is suspended over simmering water and cooked by the surrounding hot vapor without direct contact with the water. The steam transfers heat to the food while preserving its moisture, nutrients, and natural flavors. Look for food that remains moist and tender without being submerged in water or other cooking liquids.
boneless: A trick where the skater steps off with the front foot, grabs the board with the front hand, jumps, and returns to the board (a one-footed aerial trick). Look for the step-off and grab motion.
reverse point cutting: Cutting into hair ends with scissor tips angled downwards (towards the floor) relative to the hair section, used for specific texturizing effects, often on shorter hair or bangs. Look for: scissor tips pointing downwards while snipping into the hair ends.
sonic: A fundamental trick where the pen moves from one finger slot (space between fingers) to another in a conical path with one complete rotation. Most commonly performed from slot 23 (between middle and ring fingers) to slot 12 (between index and middle fingers). Look for the pen traveling upward in a circular, cone-shaped motion between finger positions. This differs from charge by the pen moving between slots rather than spinning in one place.
riposte / parade riposte: An offensive action made immediately after successfully parrying an opponent's attack. The riposte capitalizes on the opponent's extended position after their attack has been parried. In foil and sabre, a riposte has right-of-way following a successful parry. Look for the immediate offensive action following a parry.
right turn: A clockwise rotation where the dancer turns to their right, typically a 360-degree turn. This fundamental turn can be used by both leads and follows and is often employed to change directions or transition between patterns. Look for the clockwise spinning motion, which is the most common turning direction in salsa.
double loop: A loop jump with two rotations in the air. Look for the back outside edge takeoff without toe pick assistance.
hook shot: A one-handed shot taken with a sweeping motion where the shooting arm moves away from the defender in a hook-like arc, protecting the ball from being blocked. Look for the distinctive sweeping arm motion away from the defender.
saucer pass: An airborne pass that travels over obstacles (like sticks or skates) before landing flat on the ice at the recipient's position. The pass gets its name from the flying saucer-like appearance of the puck in flight.
front side 180: A trick where the skater and board rotate 180 degrees frontside (rotating with the chest facing the direction of travel) while in the air. Look for the rotation where the skater's chest faces the direction of travel.
chip return: A return of serve where the player hits with backspin using a short, chopping motion to keep the ball low and often combined with an approach to the net. An aggressive strategy to return the opponent's serve with backspin and move forward to the net for a volley. Look for the abbreviated swing and the receiver's forward momentum.
late cut: A delicate batting shot played late in the ball's trajectory, cutting it behind point with a horizontal bat. Look for the batsman waiting for the ball to come very close before gently deflecting it with a late, angled bat face.
hooking: A penalty called when a player uses their stick to restrain or impede an opponent by "hooking" it around their body, arms, or hands. This action restricts the opponent's ability to skate or play the puck.
five-second violation: A violation that occurs when a closely guarded player fails to pass, shoot, or dribble within five seconds, or when a player taking an inbound pass fails to release the ball within five seconds. Look for the referee's count with their arm extended.
rolled hem: An extremely narrow, tightly rolled edge finish typically used on delicate or lightweight fabrics. The raw edge is rolled twice into itself and sewn with small stitches, creating a very fine hem. Look for a tiny, cylindrical edge with nearly invisible stitching, commonly used on handkerchiefs, scarves, and fine garments.
juggler's tennis: A pattern where one ball repeatedly travels back and forth over the top of the others, like a tennis ball going over a net. This is typically one of the first tricks learned after the basic cascade. Look for a single ball consistently traveling over the top while others move underneath.
thattadavu 4: A foot-tapping pattern that combines single and double taps. The dancer alternates between one tap and two taps on each foot, creating an asymmetrical rhythmic pattern. This variation requires greater rhythmic awareness to execute correctly. To identify this movement, look for the alternating single and double taps that create a distinctive uneven rhythm.
lat pulldown: Sitting at a specific machine with knees secured under pads, grasping an overhead bar (usually with a wide grip), pulling the bar down towards the upper chest while keeping the torso relatively still, then controlling the bar back up. Look for: a person sitting at a machine and pulling a wide bar down from above towards their chest.
laser flip: A trick combining a 360-degree horizontal rotation of the board (full spin parallel to the ground) with a heelflip (which is a flip initiated with the heel). Look for the board spinning horizontally while flipping away from the toes.
pronator drift: Assessing for subtle upper limb weakness or proprioceptive issues by having the person hold both arms straight out in front of them with palms facing up and eyes closed for 20-30 seconds. Look for: the person holding arms outstretched with eyes closed; observe if one arm rotates inward (pronates) so the palm turns down, or drifts downward/sideways compared to the other arm.
twizzle: A traveling turn where the skater performs a one-foot turn with one or more rotations which is quickly executed. Look for a continuous turning motion while traveling across the ice, not staying in one spot.
calf raise: Standing (often with balls of feet on an elevated edge) or sitting at a machine, lifting the heels up as high as possible by pushing through the balls of the feet, pausing at the top, then lowering the heels back down, often below the level of the toes if elevated. Look for: a person lifting their heels up and down, rising onto their tiptoes.
clipper over comb: Cutting hair, usually short styles, by moving electric clippers over the surface of a comb that is held against the head; the comb acts as a guide to control the cutting length. Look for: electric clippers moving upwards across a comb that is lifting hair away from the scalp.
sonic reverse: A sonic (conical rotation transfer between slots) performed in the opposite direction, typically moving the pen from a higher slot to a lower one with reverse rotation. Look for the pen moving downward between slots with backward conical motion. This differs from regular sonic by going in the opposite direction with reverse spin.
pinching: Using the thumb and forefinger to remove the very tip (terminal bud) of a young, soft plant stem, just above a set of leaves. Look for: a person using their fingertips to nip off the soft growing point at the end of a green stem.
heading cut: Pruning by cutting off the end portion of a branch or stem just above a bud or node (which is... a point on the stem where leaves/buds emerge), stimulating growth below the cut. Look for: a person cutting the tip off a branch, leaving a bud just below the cut.
cross-field pass: A long pass played from one side of the field to the other (switching the point of attack). Look for the long, diagonal flight of the ball across the width of the field.
coin drop: A dynamic transition move where the dancer jumps and lands on their shoulder/upper back, creating the effect of a coin being dropped. The momentum from the drop is typically used to transition into another move. Look for the quick drop onto the upper back from a standing position.
eye splice: A method of creating a permanent loop in the end of rope by splicing the strands back into the standing part. Unlike knots, a splice maintains much of the rope's original strength. Look for the smooth integration of the rope's strands woven back into the main rope. This creates a strong, permanent eye that won't slip or come undone.
smoking: A cooking method where food is exposed to smoke from burning or smoldering material (usually wood) to add flavor and preserve it. This can be done hot (also cooking the food) or cold (for flavor only). Look for the distinctive smoky aroma and color changes in the food.
thattadavu 8: The most intricate foot-tapping pattern with eight distinct beats. The dancer performs eight taps distributed between both feet in a sophisticated rhythmic structure. This variation incorporates elements from all previous Thattadavu patterns, requiring complete mastery of the technique. To identify this movement, look for the elaborate eight-part tapping sequence that creates the most complex rhythmic pattern in the series.
fakie: A stance where the skater rides backward in their normal stance (moving in the opposite direction they usually face). Look for the skater standing in their regular position but moving in the opposite direction.
setenta: A Cuban salsa pattern that includes a hammerlock element. The pattern typically begins with an Exhibela, transitions to a hammerlock position, and finishes with various possible endings. Look for the characteristic hammerlock position during the middle of the pattern.
no-look pass: A pass made by a player without looking directly at the intended recipient. This deceptive technique prevents defenders from anticipating the pass direction and creates scoring opportunities.
outside hook: A skill move where a player uses the outside of their foot to quickly change direction of the ball (hooking it away from a defender). Look for the movement where the player pushes the ball away from their body with the outside of the foot.
stem stitch: A twisted outline embroidery stitch resembling a rope or twisted stem. Created by slightly overlapping each stitch with the thread consistently kept either above or below the needle. Look for a raised, twisted line with a rope-like appearance, commonly used for stems, vines, outlines, or curved lines in embroidery.
throw down: The basic yo-yo throw executed by throwing the yo-yo straight down toward the ground, typically as the initial step for most beginner tricks. Visually simple, recognizable by the downward throw direction and quick return (if responsive) or sustained spin at the end of the string. Different from sidestyle throws (Breakaway) due to its direct vertical downward orientation.
stir-frying: A quick cooking technique where small, uniformly cut pieces of food are cooked in a small amount of hot oil in a wok or pan while being constantly stirred. The high heat and continuous movement ensure that foods cook rapidly and evenly without burning. Look for food that is crisp-tender, brightly colored, and evenly cooked with slight browning on the edges.
bounce pass: A pass where the ball is bounced off the floor before reaching the receiver, typically used to pass around or under defenders. Look for the ball hitting the floor once during the pass.
illegal shift: A penalty where two or more offensive players are in motion simultaneously before the snap. Look for multiple players moving at once before the ball is snapped without getting reset.
catch-and-shoot three: A three-point shot attempt (from beyond the three-point arc) taken immediately after receiving a pass, without dribbling. Look for the quick release of the shot right after catching the ball.
braising: A combination cooking technique that uses both wet and dry heat—first searing the food at high temperature, then cooking it slowly in a covered pot with a small amount of liquid. This method tenderizes tough cuts of meat by breaking down connective tissues. Look for the two-phase cooking process and food partially submerged in liquid.
pass interference: A penalty where a player significantly hinders an eligible receiver's opportunity to catch a forward pass. Look for a defender impeding a receiver's attempt to catch the ball without playing the ball themselves.
perfection loop: A fixed loop knot that maintains its size and shape even under tension. Used particularly in fishing applications. Look for the neat, symmetrical loop with a compact knot structure. This loop knot is designed to maintain its shape and not collapse under strain.
deadman: A freeze where the dancer balances their entire body weight on both forearms with the elbows tucked into the abdomen/lower torso and the legs extended straight outward. Look for the horizontal body position with forearm support.
spin move: An offensive move where a player quickly rotates their body in a complete circle to evade a defender while maintaining their dribble or before shooting. Look for the 360-degree rotation of the player's body.
kwyjibo: An advanced trick beginning from the "Man on Trapeze" position (yo-yo resting on a horizontal string stretched between the hands). It involves popping the yo-yo vertically upward while quickly crossing and uncrossing the hands beneath it, resulting in the yo-yo landing in increasingly complex string mounts such as "Double or Nothing" (string loops twice around fingers). Visually distinctive for its dynamic hand movements and aerial pops, creating the impression that the yo-yo magically jumps from one string position to another midair. Differentiated from simpler tricks by the complexity and quick hand-crossing actions.
burnishing: A technique where the clay surface is polished to a smooth, reflective sheen without using glaze. This is done by rubbing the leather-hard clay with a hard, smooth object like a stone, spoon back, or polished tool. The process compresses the clay platelets on the surface so they align and reflect light uniformly. Look for the characteristic glossy finish without glaze application.
half hitch knot: A simple overhand knot where the working end of a line is brought over and under the standing part. Look for the basic half-turn around the standing part. This is one of the simplest knots but is not secure on its own, usually being used in combination with other hitches or knots.
double sheet bend: An enhanced version of the sheet bend used for joining two ropes of unequal thickness. The thinner rope makes two turns around the bight in the thicker rope instead of just one. Look for the extra turn around the bight of the larger rope, which adds security to the connection. This knot is especially valuable when joining ropes of significantly different diameters.
shuffle ball change: A three-sound step combining a shuffle followed by a ball change. The dancer performs a shuffle (forward-backward brush), steps on the ball of the same foot (ball), then steps on the other foot (change). Look for the distinctive rhythm pattern with the weight transfer happening after the shuffle. This differs from a simple shuffle by adding the weight transfer sequence.
scuff: A sound made by striking the floor with the heel of the foot in a forward brushing motion. The dancer swings the foot forward, making contact with the heel rather than the ball of the foot. Look for the forward heel strike with a slightly louder sound than a brush. This differs from a brush by using the heel rather than the ball of the foot.
focal onset impaired awareness seizure: A seizure originating from a restricted brain region accompanied by impaired awareness, responsiveness, or altered consciousness. During the seizure, the person appears confused or dazed, displaying repetitive or automatic behaviors such as lip-smacking, fidgeting, walking aimlessly, or engaging in purposeless motions. Although the seizure lasts for about 1-2 minutes, memory of the episode afterward remains often vague or entirely absent.
algerian eye stitch: A counted-thread embroidery stitch that creates a star-like pattern with eight straight stitches radiating from a central point. The stitches are worked in a square shape, with diagonal stitches from the corners and horizontal/vertical stitches from the sides, all meeting at the center. Look for the distinctive star or flower-like appearance with eight "legs" extending outward from a central point. This decorative stitch is often used for borders, filling areas, or as standalone decorative elements.
heelflip: A flip trick where the skater performs an ollie (which is jumping with the board) while flicking the front foot outward from the heel side of the board, causing it to rotate 360 degrees along its long axis. The board flips away from the skater's toes (opposite direction of a kickflip). Look for the distinctive outward flick motion of the front foot and the board spinning away from the toes before the skater catches and lands on it.
the windmill: A pattern where one hand throws under the arm while the other makes normal throws, creating a windmill-like motion. This is sometimes called "false shower" because it resembles the shower pattern. Look for one hand consistently throwing under the arm.
alpine butterfly loop: A knot that creates a secure, fixed loop in the middle of a rope. The loop can be loaded from any direction - from the loop to either end, between the two ends with the loop hanging free, or with force applied to the loop with load distributed between the ends. Look for a symmetrical shape with an "X" crossing pattern at the center that creates strong support in multiple directions.
blocking foul: A defensive foul that occurs when a defender impedes the movement of an offensive player without establishing legal guarding position first. Look for the defender moving or failing to establish position before contact occurs.
ascending loop: A basic calligraphy stroke that creates a loop extending above the waistline. The stroke begins with a thin upward curve that rises to the ascender line, loops around, and returns downward with increased pressure creating a thick downstroke that ends at the baseline. Look for the tall loop formation that extends upward and returns in a fluid motion.
counter: An offensive running play where the initial action goes in one direction but the ball carrier then moves in the opposite direction. Look for the offensive line blocking in one direction while the ball carrier receives the handoff going the other way.
bootleg: An offensive play where the quarterback fakes a handoff to a running back and runs in the opposite direction, often with the option to pass or run. Look for the quarterback hiding the ball after the fake and moving away from the initial flow of the play.
farmer's loop: A fixed loop knot tied in the middle of a rope when access to the ends isn't available. Similar to the Alpine Butterfly Loop but with a different tying method. Look for the stable central loop with good resistance to pulling from any direction. This versatile loop knot maintains its shape well under load.
dive roll: A rolling technique initiated with a diving motion, where the practitioner dives forward and transitions into a roll to absorb impact. Look for the diving entry followed by a smooth roll.
stemming: A technique where a climber presses their limbs in opposing directions against two facing surfaces (usually in a corner, chimney, or between features), creating pressure that holds them in place. This takes weight off the arms by using the legs' pushing power for stability. Look for a climber pressing feet or hands against opposing walls.
cover drive: A front-foot batting shot played to a ball pitched up outside the off stump, with the batsman driving the ball through the cover region. Look for an elegant forward stride and straight bat swing aimed toward the off side.
quad loop: A loop jump with four rotations in the air. Look for the back outside edge takeoff without toe pick assistance.
draw: An offensive play where the quarterback initially drops back as if to pass but then hands off to a running back. Look for the offensive line setting up in pass protection with the quarterback starting a passing motion before handing off.
spinorama: A move where a player completes a 360-degree spin while maintaining puck control to evade defenders. This high-skill maneuver can create space for a shot or pass by confusing opponents.
scorpion kick: An acrobatic technique where a player flicks their legs backward over their head to strike the ball with their heels while diving forward (resembling a scorpion's tail). Look for the player's feet going above their head while falling forward.
pull-up: Hanging from a horizontal bar with an overhand grip (palms facing away), pulling the body upwards using the back and arms until the chin clears the bar, then lowering the body back down under control. Look for: a person hanging from a bar and pulling their entire body weight up until their chin is above the bar.
ninja vanish: An impressive slack string trick where the yo-yo is momentarily popped upwards from a static or trapeze position, simultaneously creating a slack loop that instantly forms a "Green Triangle" mount around the yo-yo. Visually distinctive as the triangle formation seemingly appears spontaneously mid-air without clear intervention, resembling a stealthy ninja-like appearance. Differentiated from other slack tricks by subtle movements and instant string-triangle formation.
d\u00e9velopp\u00e9: A movement where the working leg is drawn up to the knee of the supporting leg, then extended outward to an open position, gradually unfolding. The term means "developed" or "unfolding." Look for the smooth transition from bent to extended position as the leg unfolds.
donkey kick: A basic move where the dancer kicks one or both legs backward and upward, mimicking a donkey's kick. Often used as a transition between standing and floor moves. Look for the characteristic backward kicking motion.
nose stall: A trick where the skater approaches a quarter pipe or coping (the metal edge at the top of a ramp) and stalls (temporarily stops) with only the nose (front) of the board on the edge. Look for the balanced position with the nose on the edge and the tail elevated.
flat serve: A serve hit with minimal spin that travels fast and directly toward the target. The most basic type of serve with little spin and maximum speed. Look for a straight trajectory with maximum pace and minimal bounce height.
piqu\u00e9: A step where the dancer steps directly onto the point or demi-pointe of the working foot. Commonly used in piqué turns where the dancer steps onto pointe or demi-pointe and immediately begins turning. Look for the direct, "pricked" quality of stepping onto the pointed foot.
surgeon's knot: A variation of the square knot with an extra turn in the first throw, providing additional friction to prevent slipping while the second throw is tied. Look for the extra turn in the first half of the knot. This knot is used in surgery and for secure binding when initial stability is important.
slap and fold: A vigorous bread dough kneading technique where the dough is repeatedly slapped onto a work surface and folded over itself. This develops gluten quickly in wet, sticky doughs by using the dough's stickiness to create tension. Look for the rhythmic slapping motion followed by folding.
grand battement: A large, sweeping leg movement where the working leg is raised into the air in a swift, controlled motion, then brought back down. The leg should be straight and move from the hip with maximum height. Look for the high extension of the leg at the peak of the movement.
layback: A climbing technique for ascending cracks, flakes, or arêtes where the climber pulls with their hands on one side while pushing with their feet on the opposite side, creating oppositional force. The body leans away from the holds, requiring coordination of hands and feet in a rhythmic movement. Look for a climber leaning away from the rock with straight arms.
poke check: A defensive technique where a player extends their stick to knock the puck away from an opponent. Goaltenders also use this move by jabbing their stick at an oncoming puck carrier to disrupt their control.
infinity: A continuous spinning pattern that creates an infinity symbol (∞) shape, which can be performed in multiple variations including double, triple, and reverse versions. The pen traces the horizontal figure-eight repeatedly. Look for the pen drawing the characteristic infinity symbol without stopping. This differs from figure 8 by the continuous horizontal pattern rather than a vertical hourglass shape.
basting stitch: A temporary, long running stitch used to hold fabric pieces together before permanent stitching. Made with long, loose stitches that are easily removed by pulling the thread, this stitch is ideal for testing garment fit or temporarily securing layers. Look for widely spaced, straight stitches that create a dashed line pattern and are intentionally loose for easy removal.
half back stitch: A variation of the back stitch where the needle is brought forward only halfway through the previous stitch rather than all the way back. This creates a line that has more texture and is less solid than a regular back stitch. Look for a line that appears slightly gapped compared to the regular back stitch. This stitch provides a lighter outline option when a solid line would be too heavy for delicate work.
smith grind: A grind (which is when the metal trucks scrape along an object) where the back truck rides on top of the obstacle while the front truck hangs below the edge (the board is at an angle with the nose pointing down). Look for the distinctive position with the front truck below the ledge.
running subcuticular stitch: A continuous suture placed entirely hidden within the dermis (which is the skin layer just below the visible surface), running horizontally back and forth beneath the joined edges. Look for: a wound closure where no stitches are visible on the skin surface, only entry/exit points or knots at the ends.
instrument tie: Tying surgical knots using a tool, typically a needle holder, by wrapping the suture around the instrument's jaws and using the jaws to grasp and pull the suture end through to form the knot. Look for: a person using a needle holder tool to wrap and manipulate suture thread to form and tighten knots.
suicide pass: A dangerous pass that puts the receiving teammate in a vulnerable position where they could be severely hit by an opponent. Typically, these passes force the receiver to look away from oncoming defenders.
doubleflip: A kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis) where the board completes two full rotations along its long axis (flipping twice). Look for the extended flipping motion.
manger hitch: A quick-release knot traditionally used to secure livestock to a manger or post. Look for the characteristic loop formation that provides reasonable security while allowing for quick release when needed. This specialized hitch is designed for temporary animal restraint.
double toe loop: A toe loop jump with two rotations in the air. Look for the back outside edge takeoff with toe pick assistance.
ladder escape: A highly technical trick involving multiple intricate string maneuvers, beginning usually from a mount like "Double or Nothing." The player creates and navigates through a complex arrangement of interwoven string segments resembling ladder rungs. Visually identifiable by the yo-yo threading precisely through tight string openings in sequence, as if escaping through layers of a tangled ladder. Distinguished from simpler mounts by the complexity and precision required to resolve the trick without creating knots.
leg wrap: A flashy trick where the player throws the yo-yo horizontally around their leg, typically from a sideways (Breakaway) throw or forward toss (Forward Pass). The yo-yo visually loops completely around the player's extended leg before returning smoothly to the hand. Differentiated from standard looping by the deliberate interaction with the player's body, creating a noticeable circular trajectory around the leg.
pas de cheval: A movement resembling a horse pawing the ground. The working foot slides forward along the floor to a pointed position, then bends at the ankle and is drawn back to the supporting leg. Look for the pawing motion that gives this step its name.
push whip shading: A shading technique similar to pull whip, but the needle grouping (often round shaders or liners) is flicked into the skin towards the direction of hand movement (pushing the machine away from the body often results in the flick moving towards a point). This creates a gradient that starts lighter or as dots and becomes darker where the flick ends. Look for: the artist making quick, flicking motions towards a specific point or line, often pushing the machine away from themselves, creating shading that starts light/dotty and darkens as it reaches the target point.
acid drop: A trick where the skater jumps directly from a higher surface onto a lower surface without an ollie (jumping with the board). Look for the direct drop without the popping motion.
plastic whip: A one-handed whip trick wherein a loop of slack string is whipped underneath and around the yo-yo, resulting in it instantly landing onto an undermount (yo-yo hanging on string loop from below). Visually recognizable by the quick upward flicking motion, instantly snagging the yo-yo onto the string. Differentiates clearly from other whips by its underneath catch and immediate undermount formation.
backcombing: Creating volume by holding a section of hair taut away from the head and using a comb to repeatedly push the hair down towards the scalp, matting the hair near the roots. Look for: a comb moving against the natural direction of hair growth, pushing hair downwards towards the scalp within a held section.
pli\u00e9: A bending of the knees while maintaining turnout from the hips. The foundational movement of ballet from which all jumps begin and end. Can be demi-plié (half bend) or grand plié (full bend). Look for the controlled, smooth bending with heels on the floor (except in second position grand plié).
no look pass: A deceptive pass where the player looks in one direction but passes the ball in another direction to confuse defenders. Look for the passer's eyes not focused on the actual target of their pass.
knockback: A bread-making technique where partially risen dough is gently pressed or folded to release excess gas bubbles before final shaping. This redistributes yeast and helps create a more even crumb structure. Look for the deflating and folding action after the first rise.
hand hop: A dynamic move where the dancer hops on their hands while maintaining a freeze-like position. Often done from a turtle position or hand glide. Look for the rhythmic bouncing on the hands with the body held above the ground.
double kong vault: An advanced vault where the practitioner performs two consecutive kong vaults (placing both hands down while diving over an obstacle) with two hand placements on an extended obstacle. Look for the double hand placement during the pass.
lazy daisy stitch: A variation of the chain stitch where individual loops are anchored at the end to create petal shapes, also known as detached chain stitch. Each stitch begins and ends at the same point, with a loop extending outward that is anchored by a small holding stitch. Look for the teardrop or petal-shaped loops that can be arranged in flower patterns. This stitch is perfect for creating flower petals, leaves, and decorative accents.
bee sting: A counterweight trick (5A) involving continuous releases and re-catches of the counterweight (a small object tied opposite the yo-yo on the string). Visually noticeable as the counterweight and yo-yo alternate circling around the player's hand, resembling a figure-eight pattern. Distinguished by the alternating movement of the weight and yo-yo around the hand.
top shelf: A shot that goes into the upper part of the net, just under the crossbar. This hard-to-reach area of the goal is particularly difficult for goaltenders to protect, especially when they drop into butterfly position.
dividing dough: Dividing dough is cutting or portioning a larger mass into smaller, equal pieces for baking. Look for hands/tools separating the dough, often with weighing, cutting with bench scrapers, or pinching off portions. The divided pieces typically appear uniform in size on the work surface.
tendu: A movement where the working foot slides from a closed position to an extended position without leaving the floor, stretching the leg and pointing the foot. The term means "stretched." Look for the fully extended foot and leg with the toe still touching the floor.
reverse layup: A layup shot where the player approaches the basket from one side but shoots from the opposite side of the hoop, using the rim to protect the ball from defenders. Look for the player shooting on the opposite side of the rim from where they approached.
flag freeze: A freeze where the dancer supports their body weight on one hand while holding their body horizontally with legs extended, resembling a flag. The free arm is typically punched forward for balance. Look for the horizontal body position supported by just one arm.
blind baking: The process of pre-baking a pie or pastry crust without its filling, often using weights to prevent bubbling or rising. This technique creates a crisp base for pies with wet fillings that might otherwise make the crust soggy. Look for an empty crust being partially baked before the filling is added.
maradona spin: A skill move where a player places one foot on top of the ball, rotates 360 degrees while dragging the ball along, and exits in a new direction. Look for the complete spinning motion while controlling the ball.
bank shot: A shot that deliberately bounces off the boards or glass before reaching its intended target, such as another player or the goal. This technique is used to navigate around opponents or create unexpected angles.
knee bar: A specialized rest position where a climber wedges their knee and foot between surfaces to create opposing pressure that holds their body in place without using hands. This provides a hands-free rest on routes with appropriate features. Look for a climber pressing with both their knee and foot in opposite directions.
toss: A type of pitch to a running back that is generally directed to the outside. Look for the quarterback tossing the ball to a running back who is moving laterally toward the sideline.
bent-over row: Bending forward at the hips with a flat back (torso angled towards the floor), pulling a barbell or dumbbells up towards the stomach or lower chest by retracting the shoulder blades and bending the elbows, then lowering the weight back down. Look for: a person bent over, pulling a weight towards their torso.
death spiral: A pairs element where the man rotates in a pivot position while holding one hand of his partner, who is rotating in a horizontal position around him with her body low and parallel to the ice.
qb sneak: A play where the quarterback takes the snap and immediately plunges forward behind the center, usually for a short gain. Look for the quarterback taking the snap and immediately moving forward with little to no backfield action.
hardflip: A trick combining a frontside shuvit (horizontal board rotation toward the toes) with a kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis), making the board appear to flip vertically through the legs. Look for the distinctive vertical rotation path of the board.
flamb\u00e9ing: A cooking procedure where alcohol is added to a hot pan and deliberately ignited to create a burst of flames for both flavor enhancement and visual effect. The flames burn off some of the alcohol while leaving behind subtle flavors from the liquor or liqueur. Look for the dramatic, controlled burning of alcohol over food, which is commonly done with desserts like Bananas Foster or savory dishes like Steak Diane.
fasciculations: Small, rapid, involuntary muscle twitches or contractions (which are brief shortenings of muscle fibers) visible under the skin, without causing movement of the entire limb or joint. They represent the spontaneous firing of a group of muscle fibers. Look for: fine, flickering, quivering, or rippling movements just beneath the skin surface in a muscle (like the calf, thigh, arm, or eyelid); the limb itself does not move position due to these twitches.
cruyff turn: A technique where a player fakes a pass or shot, then quickly drags the ball behind their standing leg with the inside of their foot and turns 180 degrees. Look for the player's sudden change of direction after the fake.
flare: A power move originally from gymnastics where the dancer swings both legs in circular motions around the body while supporting their weight on their hands. The legs move in a V-shape without touching the ground. Look for the dynamic circular leg swinging while hands remain planted.
skin rolling: Lifting a fold of skin and the underlying superficial tissues (which are... the layers just beneath the skin) between the thumbs and fingers, and then rolling this fold along the body by moving the fingers forward while the thumbs push from behind. Look for: therapist pinching a roll of skin and moving this roll across the body surface.
absence seizure: A brief seizure lasting typically less than 15 seconds, characterized by a sudden loss of focus and awareness. A person experiencing this event will abruptly stop their current activity, stare blankly into space, and become momentarily unresponsive to their surroundings. Subtle signs such as fluttering eyelids or slight mouth movements may accompany the episode but often go unnoticed. Immediately after the seizure, the person usually regains normal alertness and is unaware an episode occurred. This type of seizure is common in childhood and can affect learning, attention, and daily function if occurring frequently.
forehand volley: A volley hit using the forehand stroke, with the palm facing forward at contact, typically executed near the net. Typically executed near the net with a stiff-wristed punching motion. Look for the player positioned at net using their dominant side to punch the ball out of the air.
cambr\u00e9: A bending movement of the upper body from the waist, either forward, backward, or sideways. The head follows the movement of the upper body, creating a graceful arch. Look for the arched position of the back while the lower body remains stable.
windmill dunk: A stylish dunk where the player rotates the ball in a circular windmill-like motion with an extended arm before dunking it. Look for the circular arm motion before the ball goes through the hoop.
thattadavu 7: A foot-tapping pattern based on groups of seven. The dancer performs seven taps distributed between both feet in a specific pattern that creates complex rhythmic phrases. This variation requires significant rhythmic precision to execute correctly. To identify this movement, look for the seven-part tapping sequence that creates a longer rhythmic cycle than previous variations.
waterfall: A flair bartending pour where liquid flows from multiple stacked mixing tins simultaneously. The bartender arranges several tins in a vertical stack with their edges aligned, then tilts them to create a cascading effect as the contents pour from each tin in sequence, allowing for efficient and visually impressive service of multiple drinks at once.
yarn under: An alternative technique to yarn over where the working yarn is wrapped under the hook from front to back before pulling through loops. This creates a tighter, more defined stitch than the standard yarn over method. Yarn under is particularly popular in amigurumi and other projects where a dense fabric is desired. The technique produces stitches that appear more "crossed" or "X-shaped" when viewed closely, compared to the "V-shaped" appearance of yarn over stitches. Many crocheters find this method helps reduce holes in fabric worked in the round.
herringbone stitch: A decorative cross-stitch forming a zigzag pattern with interlocking X-shapes. Made with slanted stitches that cross each other, creating a woven appearance. Look for a series of crossed diagonal stitches forming a zigzag pattern, often used for securing hems, decorative borders, or adding texture to embroidery.
pinwheel: A flourish or transitional move where the yo-yo, attached to the string, is swung around the player's hand in continuous, circular motions. Visually similar to a windmill or propeller, distinguished from other tricks by being primarily used as a stylish intermediary maneuver rather than a concluding action or complicated mount.
counter riposte: An offensive action that follows the parry of an opponent's riposte. If the initial attacker parries the defender's riposte, the subsequent offensive action is called a counter-riposte. Multiple exchanges can lead to second or third counter-ripostes within a fencing phrase. Look for the back-and-forth sequence of attack-parry-riposte-parry-counter-riposte.
drop in: A technique used to enter a ramp or bowl (which are curved skating surfaces) where the skater places the tail of the board on the edge of the ramp, shifts their weight forward, and rides down the transition (which is the curved part of the ramp). Look for the initial position with the tail on the edge before committing to the descent.
assembl\u00e9: A jump that begins with one foot sliding along the floor before brushing into the air, where both legs join together at the peak of the jump before landing. The name translates to "assembled" or "joined together." Look for the moment when both legs come together in the air before the dancer lands, typically in fifth position.
chiffonade: A slicing technique used for leafy herbs and vegetables where the leaves are stacked, rolled into a tight cylinder, then cut into thin ribbon-like strips. This method creates delicate, uniform strips that distribute flavor evenly and make an attractive garnish. Look for the thin, ribbon-like appearance of the cut herbs or greens.
magic circle / magic ring: A technique for starting projects worked in the round that allows you to pull the center completely closed. It creates a secure beginning with no hole in the center, making it ideal for amigurumi and other projects requiring a tight center. Look for the completely closed center with no visible opening.
blocked punt: A defensive play where a defender prevents a punt from traveling downfield by deflecting or stopping the kicked ball. Look for a defender breaking through the line and getting to the punter before or just as the ball is kicked.
deadheading: Removing old, faded, or spent flower heads from a plant by pinching them off with fingers or snipping them with small cutters, often cutting just below the flower head. Look for: a person selectively removing individual withered flowers from a plant.
farrimond friction hitch: A secure friction hitch used for climbing or adjustable tension applications. Look for the distinctive crossing pattern that provides strong grip in one direction but allows controlled movement when desired. This specialized friction hitch provides good security while allowing adjustment.
wall spin: A rotational movement where the practitioner approaches a wall at an angle and uses it to spin their body around. Look for the spinning motion while maintaining contact with the wall.
poaching: A gentle cooking method where food is cooked in liquid maintained at a low temperature (160-180°F/71-82°C), with small bubbles occasionally rising to the surface. This preserves the delicate texture of foods like eggs, fish, and fruits. Look for the barely simmering liquid with food fully submerged.
marinating: The technique of soaking food (typically meat, fish, or vegetables) in a seasoned liquid mixture to add flavor and sometimes tenderize. The acidic components in marinades help break down tough fibers in meat. Look for food immersed in a flavored liquid before cooking.
head spin: A power move where the dancer spins balanced solely on their head with legs in various positions (straight up, V-shape, tucked, etc.). Look for the continuous rotation with only the head in contact with the floor.
scratch spin: An upright spin where the skater extends their free leg in front of them with their knee bent. As the skater brings their free leg down and crosses over the ankle of the spinning leg while drawing the arms in, the spin accelerates.
tour en l'air: A jump with a full turn in the air, typically performed by male dancers. The dancer springs into the air from both feet, turns completely, and lands in fifth position. Look for the complete rotation in the air while the body remains vertical.
paddle scoop: An unorthodox batting shot where the batsman gets low and uses the bat as a ramp to scoop the ball over the wicketkeeper's head. Look for the batsman crouching with the bat held horizontally to redirect the ball over his shoulder.
rdt (ross droplet technique): A method where a small amount of water is applied to coffee beans before grinding. Look for the slight dampening of beans before they enter the grinder and the reduction in coffee grounds sticking to surfaces after grinding.
rubenstein's revenge: A complex three-ball pattern created by Rick Rubenstein that involves intricate arm crossings, carries, and throws. It's considered one of the most difficult of the named arm-crossing patterns. Look for the complex sequence of arm crosses combined with carries.
takeouts: A variation of the 423 pattern where one ball (the "4") is carried through the pattern rather than thrown. Similar to Burke's Barrage but with different timing and execution. Look for one ball being carried through the pattern while others follow a crossing path.
sombrero: A turn pattern executed with crossed hands where the hands are raised over the head in a shape resembling a sombrero (hat). The dancer's hands are crossed over left hands, then dropped over each person's head at the end of the turn. Look for the hands passing over the head in the characteristic hat-like shape.
ice shaving: A technique where ice is manually shaved into fine, snow-like particles for use in specific cocktails. The bartender uses a specialized tool or sharp implement to scrape across a block of ice, creating delicate ice shavings that provide unique texture and rapid cooling to drinks without excessive dilution.
disaster: A trick where the skater approaches a quarter pipe or coping (the metal edge at the top of a ramp) and lands with both trucks on the far side of the coping (completely crossing over the edge). Look for the position where the board has completely crossed over the edge.
rainbow flick: A skill move where a player rolls the ball up the back of one leg, then flicks it overhead with the other heel, sending the ball in an arc over a defender. Look for the arcing movement of the ball over the opponent's head.
retir\u00e9: A position where the working foot is drawn up and placed at the knee of the supporting leg. Can be to the front, side, or back of the knee. Often used as part of other movements like pirouettes. Look for the precise placement of the working foot at the knee.
under the leg: A trick where throws are made from under a raised leg. The juggler lifts one leg and throws a ball underneath it, requiring flexibility and timing. Look for the deliberate leg-raising motion combined with a throw underneath.
pricking out: Carefully transplanting very small seedlings from a crowded seed tray into individual pots or cells when they have their first true leaves (which are... the second set of leaves that resemble the adult plant). Look for: a person gently lifting tiny seedlings, often by a leaf, and moving them one by one into separate small containers.
shaking: A fundamental bartending technique where ingredients are vigorously mixed in a shaker with ice. The bartender combines ingredients in a shaker, seals it properly, and agitates it forcefully for about 10-15 seconds, simultaneously chilling, diluting, and mixing the cocktail while incorporating air for proper texture.
delay of game: A penalty called when a player or team deliberately stalls or prevents play from continuing. Common examples include shooting the puck over the glass from the defensive zone or a goalie freezing the puck unnecessarily.
tricep pushdown: Standing at a cable machine with a high pulley, grasping a bar or rope attachment with an overhand or neutral grip, pushing the attachment straight down by extending the elbows until the arms are fully straight, keeping upper arms stationary at the sides, then controlling the attachment back up. Look for: a person pushing a cable attachment downwards using only their forearms, keeping elbows pinned to their sides.
under the arm: A trick involving throws made from under the arm rather than in the normal throwing position. The ball travels under the opposite arm before being caught. Look for the characteristic under-arm throwing motion rather than standard throwing positions.
wall run: A technique where the practitioner runs vertically up a wall to gain height, using forward momentum and proper foot placement. Look for the characteristic running motion against a vertical surface.
fs shuvit: A shuvit (horizontal board rotation) where the board rotates frontside (toward the skater's toes) instead of the standard backside direction. Look for the board rotating in the opposite direction of a standard shuvit.
cardioid: A combination trick that joins a thumb around (where the pen rotates 360 degrees around the thumb) with a wiper motion (side-to-side pendulum movement) to create a heart-shaped pattern. The pen first completes a full rotation around the thumb, then transitions into a lateral oscillating movement. Look for the combined movement that traces a cardioid (heart) shape. This differs from a standard thumb around by adding the wiper component to create the distinctive heart pattern.
tapotement cupping: Striking the body rhythmically with hands cupped (fingers and thumb forming a hollow curve), trapping air to create a hollow, muffled sound upon impact. A form of tapotement (which is... a category of rapid, rhythmic, percussive massage strokes). Look for: therapist using curved hands to repeatedly strike the client's body, often the back, producing a distinct hollow popping or plopping sound.
precision jump: A controlled jump where the practitioner lands precisely on a specific target, emphasizing accuracy over distance. Look for the careful takeoff and exact landing on a small target.
bicycle kick: An acrobatic move where a player leaps in the air with their back to the goal, kicks the ball overhead while their body is parallel to the ground (resembling a cycling motion), and then lands on their back. Look for the player launching into the air and kicking with their back to the goal.
single time step: A foundational rhythm pattern used to establish tempo, traditionally starting on count 8. The dancer performs a shuffle, hop, step, tap, and ball change in a specific rhythm. Look for the distinctive seven-beat pattern that travels minimally. This differs from double and triple time steps by having fewer sounds between the shuffle and final ball change.
trench: A step performed in either Hoofer style (emphasizing foot sounds) or Broadway style (more theatrical). The dancer executes a series of heel-focused movements with distinct rhythm patterns. Look for the intricate heel work and distinctive side-to-side movement. This differs from other heel steps by its specific rhythm pattern and styling variations.
meltdown: A visually dynamic 5A (counterweight) trick involving aerial releases and catches of the yo-yo or counterweight, typically starting from a stable string mount. Visually distinct as the yo-yo or counterweight briefly leaves the player's grasp mid-air, creating a dramatic free-fall effect before re-catching. This aerial element clearly distinguishes it from non-aerial 5A tricks or basic string holds.
enchufla: A basic figure in Cuban salsa that involves changing places with your partner. The dancers exchange positions through a series of steps and turns. Look for the characteristic change of place pattern that serves as a foundation for many other Cuban salsa combinations.
beamer: A dangerous delivery where the ball reaches the batsman at waist height or above without bouncing on the pitch. Look for the full-pitched ball traveling directly from the bowler's hand to the batsman without hitting the ground.
triple crochet: Also called treble crochet, this is a tall stitch formed by yarning over twice before inserting the hook, then pulling up a loop and completing by drawing yarn through two loops at a time three times. Look for the extra-tall stitch that's approximately three times the height of a single crochet.
heel stretch: A stunt position where the flyer stands on one leg and lifts the other leg up toward their head, holding it by the heel or middle of the foot with one hand. Look for the vertical split position with one hand holding the raised foot at eye level or higher.
