lembert suture: An inverting suture technique (which is one that turns tissue edges inward) where the needle takes bites perpendicular to the wound edge, entering and exiting further back from the edge on each side through outer layers, used on hollow organs. Look for: stitches entering and exiting tissue relatively far from the wound edge, causing edges to roll inward (often internal).
drop pass: A pass where a player leaves the puck behind for a trailing teammate while continuing to skate forward. This creates confusion for defenders who must quickly adjust to the new puck carrier.
deep-frying: A cooking method where food is completely submerged in hot oil or fat heated to between 350-375°F (175-190°C). This creates a crispy exterior while cooking the interior quickly. Look for food completely immersed in bubbling oil, resulting in a golden-brown crust.
folding in / folding: A gentle mixing technique used to combine light, airy ingredients (like whipped egg whites) with denser ingredients without deflating the air bubbles. Using a spatula, the mixture is cut down the center and portions are turned over onto themselves. Look for the careful, sweeping motion that maintains volume in the mixture.
onside kick: A kickoff designed to be recovered by the kicking team after the ball travels 10 yards. Look for a short kickoff with players from the kicking team converging quickly to try to recover the ball.
dash vault: A vault technique (which is passing over obstacles using the hands) where the practitioner jumps feet-first over an obstacle, placing both hands down mid-flight to control the pass. Look for the seated position midway through the vault.
palm flip: A flip initiated from a wall where the practitioner places one or both hands on the wall and uses them to push off into a backward flip. Look for the flip starting from contact with a wall.
360: A turn where the dancer makes a complete 360-degree rotation while traveling forward. This differs from a spot turn because the dancer moves through space rather than turning in one fixed position. Look for the dancer making a full circle while simultaneously moving forward along a path.
dumbbell shrug: Standing or sitting holding dumbbells at the sides, elevating the shoulders straight up towards the ears in a shrugging motion, without bending the elbows, then lowering the shoulders back down. Look for: a person lifting only their shoulders straight up and down while holding weights at their sides.
padded satin stitch: A dimensional version of satin stitch where an area is first built up with padding stitches, then covered with closely placed parallel stitches. The padding can be created with running or seed stitches in the same or contrasting color. Look for the raised, smooth surface with a luxurious sheen created by the close parallel stitches. This technique is perfect for creating dimensional elements like flower centers, berries, or motifs that need to stand out from the fabric.
front essence: A fundamental tap step where the dancer shifts weight forward while creating rhythmic patterns with the feet. The dancer alternates brushing the foot forward, stepping, and shifting weight. Look for the continuous forward movement pattern with a distinctive heel-toe rhythm. This differs from Back Essence by moving forward rather than backward.
skull crusher: Lying face-up on a bench, holding a barbell or dumbbells with arms extended straight up above the chest, lowering the weight towards the forehead or just behind the head by bending only the elbows, then extending the arms back to the starting position. Look for: a person lying on a bench, lowering a weight towards their forehead by bending their elbows.
single sheet bend: A bend knot used to join two ropes, especially effective for joining ropes of unequal thickness. Look for the thinner rope wrapped around the bight of the thicker rope with its end tucked under itself. This practical knot is easily tied and generally secure for non-critical applications.
catch: A method of dismissal where a fielder catches the ball directly after it has been hit by the batsman and before it touches the ground. Look for the batsman hitting the ball in the air and a fielder successfully grabbing it.
dystonic tremor: An involuntary sustained shaking or tremor resulting from abnormal muscle contractions, causing twisting, repetitive movements, or unusual body postures. Dystonic tremor tends to worsen when attempting precise movements or holding a specific posture. The disorder can significantly hinder daily activities—such as holding objects, writing, or fine motor tasks—and may originate from neurological conditions, certain medications, or genetic predisposition.
540 flip: A trick combining a 540-degree horizontal rotation of the board (one and a half rotations) with a kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis). Look for the extended rotation compared to a 360 flip.
half double crochet: A basic stitch with a height between single and double crochet. Formed by yarning over once before inserting the hook, then pulling up a loop and completing by drawing yarn through all three loops at once. Look for the medium-height stitch that's taller than single crochet but shorter than double crochet.
double salchow: A salchow jump with two rotations in the air. Look for the back inside edge takeoff without toe pick assistance.
air layering: Wounding a stem still attached to the parent plant, wrapping the wound with moist material (like moss), and covering it with plastic or foil to encourage root growth for propagation (which is... creating new plants). Look for: a person wrapping a bundle around a stem that's still part of a living plant.
tape-to-tape pass: A perfectly executed pass that goes directly from the blade of one player's stick to another's. The name refers to the stick tape where players wrap their blades for better puck control.
freehand clipper cut: Using electric clippers directly on the hair without clipper guards or a comb, shaping the hair based purely on the stylist's hand movements and visual judgment. Look for: clippers cutting hair without any comb or plastic guard guiding them, moving fluidly to sculpt the style.
elastico / flip flap: A skill move where a player uses the outside of their foot to push the ball one way, then quickly uses the inside of the same foot to take it in the opposite direction. Look for the quick change of direction of the ball.
hail mary: A long forward pass thrown as time expires with little chance of success. Look for a quarterback throwing a high, arcing pass toward the end zone with multiple receivers and defenders jumping to catch it.
slap shot: A powerful shot where the player brings their stick back and then forcefully forward, striking the ice slightly behind the puck to create flex in the stick. This generates maximum velocity but takes longer to execute.
squib kick: A low, short kickoff designed to prevent a return by bouncing along the ground. Look for a kick that travels close to the ground and bounces multiple times rather than sailing through the air.
jump stop: A technique where a player stops their movement by landing on both feet simultaneously after dribbling or receiving a pass. Look for both feet landing at the same time rather than in a one-two step.
fair catch: A receiver's signal (by waving one arm above their head) that they will catch a punt or kickoff but not advance it, preventing them from being tackled. Look for the receiver raising their arm and waving it above their head before catching the ball and making no attempt to run.
compound curve: A combined stroke that merges an overturn and underturn into one fluid motion. It begins with a thin upstroke that curves at the top, transitions into a thick downstroke that reaches the baseline, and then curves up again ending with a thin upstroke. Look for the S-like shape with parallel lines and consistent thickness transitions.
swipe: A power move where the dancer rotates their body horizontally around their vertical axis, supporting their weight on their hands. The legs swing in a circular motion as the hands alternate supporting the body. Look for the fluid circular rotation near the ground with hand support.
v stitch: A simple lacy pattern created by working two stitches (usually double crochets) separated by a chain space into the same stitch. This creates a series of "V" shapes across the fabric. Look for the repeated V-shaped openings that create a light, airy texture.
bust: A type of fingerless around (where the pen rotates around a finger without direct finger contact) executed with an upward bump motion from an adjacent finger. Instead of pushing the pen with a finger, the spinner uses an upward thrust from the finger next to the target finger to propel the pen into rotation. Look for the distinctive upward "bump" that launches the pen and the complete rotation around a finger without touching. This differs from regular backarounds by the specific upward starting motion.
backside heelflip: A combination trick where the skater performs a heelflip (which is a flip initiated with the heel instead of the toe) while rotating their body and board 180 degrees backside (rotating with the back facing the direction of travel). Look for the board flipping away from the toes while the skater rotates backside.
corner kick: A set piece (stopped play restart) awarded when the ball crosses the goal line after last touching a defending player. Look for a player positioning the ball in the corner arc before kicking.
romberg test: Assessing balance and proprioception (which is the sense of body position without looking) by having the person stand with feet together, first with eyes open, and then with eyes closed. Look for: the person standing still with feet touching; observe their steadiness with eyes open, then note any increased sway or loss of balance when they close their eyes.
push cut: A basic whittling technique where the knife is pushed away from the body, creating controlled cuts through the wood. Often performed with both thumbs positioned behind the blade to add stability and force—one thumb from the knife hand and one from the hand holding the wood. This cut provides excellent control for removing precise amounts of material and is generally safer than the pull cut as the blade moves away from the body. Visual identification: Look for the carver pushing the knife forward with thumbs positioned behind the blade.
tackle: A defensive action where a player attempts to take the ball away from an opponent (using the feet to challenge for possession). Look for the defender extending their leg to win the ball.
snell knot: A specialized fishing knot used to attach a hook to a leader so that the hook extends in line with the leader. Look for the tight wraps around both the hook shank and the main line. This knot creates a strong, aligned connection between hook and line.
loose ball foul: A foul called when players from opposing teams are competing for a ball that neither team has possession of. Look for excessive contact between players trying to gain possession of a free ball.
tonic-clonic seizure: A seizure combining two phases—an initial stiffening (tonic phase) followed immediately by rhythmic muscle jerking (clonic phase). During the episode, the affected person generally loses consciousness, experiences generalized bodily stiffening followed by strong repetitive muscle contractions, and may display breath-holding, tongue biting, or loss of bladder control. Afterward, normal consciousness returns gradually, often accompanied by fatigue, confusion, or soreness.
saccades: Assessing the rapid eye movements used to shift gaze between two points. The examiner typically holds up two targets (e.g., fingers) and asks the person to look back and forth between them quickly on command. Look for: the person's eyes making quick jumps between two points; observe the speed, accuracy (hitting the target, not over- or undershooting), and smoothness of the initiation of the jump.
diamond knot: A decorative stopper knot that creates a distinctive diamond-shaped or spherical knot formation. Often used at the end of a lanyard or as a decorative element in rope work. Look for the interwoven diamond pattern with multiple tucks that create a solid, rounded knot. This is both a functional stopper and an attractive decorative element.
twisted sonic: A hybrid trick combining a charge motion (conical spin in place) with a pass (0.5 rotation transfer), resulting in 1.5 total rotations while transferring between slots. The pen performs more rotation than a regular sonic while moving between positions. Look for the distinctive 1.5 spin pattern during slot transfer. This differs from regular sonic by the additional half rotation and combined charge-pass technique.
backhand volley: A volley (ball struck before it bounces) hit using the backhand stroke, with the back of the racquet hand facing the ball at contact. Typically executed near the net with a stiff-wristed punching motion. Look for the player positioned at or inside the service line using their non-dominant side to punch the ball out of the air.
spider spin: A trick where the pen spins on the knuckle-side of bent fingers, typically with the hand in a devil's horn shape (index and pinky extended, middle fingers bent inward). Look for the distinctive hand position with pen rotating on the back of bent fingers. This differs from palm spin by using the knuckles rather than palm surface for rotation.
nattadavu 4: A detailed leg stretching movement where each position is held for an extended duration. This variation repeats each movement of Nattadavu 3 twice, creating a slower, more deliberate quality. The dancer extends the leg, holds the position, and then continues to the next movement with deliberate control. To identify this movement, look for the doubled timing of each position compared to Nattadavu 3, with extended holds in each stretched position.     (For context, here is a definition for Nattadavu 3: A leg stretching movement that adds directional changes. The dancer extends one leg to the side, then forward, creating a more complex pattern of movements. Each leg extension is precise and deliberate, with the dancer maintaining perfect balance throughout. The corresponding arm movements enhance the geometric patterns created by the legs. To identify this movement, look for the multi-directional leg extensions executed with control and precision.)
sailmaker's whipping: A method of securing the end of a rope to prevent fraying by wrapping thread tightly around it and securing the wraps with a series of interwoven tucks. Look for the neat, professional finish with no exposed thread ends. This creates a permanent, durable rope end finish.
axle stall: A trick where the skater approaches a quarter pipe or coping (the metal edge at the top of a ramp) and stalls (temporarily stops) with the back truck (axle) on the edge (balancing on the metal axle). Look for the position with the back truck resting on the edge.
columns: A pattern where balls are thrown in straight vertical lines rather than arcs, with each ball following its own dedicated path. In the three-ball version, the outside balls are thrown simultaneously, with the center ball thrown when the outside balls are caught. Look for balls moving in straight up-and-down paths rather than arcing between hands.
spiral wedging: A clay preparation technique where clay is repetitively folded and pressed in a spiral pattern to remove air bubbles and achieve consistent texture. The potter presses down on one side of the clay while slightly turning it with each press, creating a spiral pattern inside the clay. Look for the spiral marks visible when clay is cut and the improved consistency in the clay body.
jasmine stitch: A complex decorative stitch that creates clusters of petals resembling a jasmine flower. It involves multiple yarn overs and pulls through the same stitch in a specific arrangement. Look for the flower-like clusters with multiple raised "petals" extending from a central point.
penalty kick: A set piece (stopped play restart) awarded when a foul occurs inside the penalty area, allowing a player to take an undefended shot from the penalty spot. Look for a player placing the ball on the spot 12 yards from goal.
multiplex: A technique where two or more balls are thrown simultaneously from the same hand. These can be thrown as a "stack" where balls follow the same path, or "split" where they follow different trajectories. Look for multiple balls being thrown together from one hand.
suzy q / suzie q: A footwork step or "shine" where the dancer twists their feet alternately while stepping slightly to the side. It involves swiveling on the heel with the toe swinging to the side, then transferring weight to the other foot. Look for the characteristic twisting foot motion with alternating weight transfers.
killick hitch: A hitch used to attach a rope to an awkwardly shaped object, traditionally used to secure a stone anchor (killick). Look for the timber hitch with a half hitch added for stability. This specialized hitch provides good grip on irregular objects.
stretch pass: A long pass that travels from the defensive zone to a teammate near or beyond the far blue line. This offensive strategy attempts to catch the opposing defense unprepared and create breakaway opportunities.
bowled out: A method of dismissal where the ball hits the stumps directly from the bowler, dislodging the bails. Look for the ball passing the batsman's bat or body and striking the wicket.
arm roll: A flair bartending technique where the bottle or object is rolled down the arm in a controlled manner, often from the hand, along the arm, and potentially across the chest or behind the back. This creates a flowing, continuous motion as the object travels across the bartender's body, requiring precise timing and balance to maintain control throughout.
flick shot: A wristy batting shot played to deliveries on the leg stump or middle stump, where the batsman uses his wrists to flick the ball toward the leg side. Look for minimal backlift and quick wrist rotation directing the ball between mid-wicket and fine leg.
inward heelflip: A trick combining a backside shuvit (horizontal board rotation away from the toes) with a heelflip (which is a flip initiated with the heel). Look for the board spinning inward toward the skater while flipping away from the heels.
360 flip: A trick combining a 360-degree horizontal rotation of the board (full spin parallel to the ground) with a kickflip (flipping the board along its long axis). Also known as a "tre flip." Look for the simultaneous spinning and flipping motions.
in & out: A dribbling move where the player fakes a crossover by moving the ball to one side but then quickly brings it back to the original side, deceiving the defender. Look for the ball starting to move to one side before returning to the original side.
lache: A swinging release movement where the practitioner swings on a bar and releases at the peak of the swing to grab another bar or object. Look for the swinging motion followed by a release and catch.
sit spin: A spin where the skater spins in a "sitting" position, with the upper part of the skating leg at least parallel to the ice. Look for the thigh of the skating leg to be parallel to the ice.
smearing: A footwork technique that relies on friction rather than standing on an edge, where the climber presses the rubber of their shoe directly against the rock without a defined foothold. Maximum rubber contact and downward pressure create the necessary friction. Look for a climber pressing the ball of their foot against a blank section of wall.
candado: A move in rueda de casino (group salsa dancing) that involves a series of turns and hand changes. It typically follows other moves such as enchufla in a sequence. Look for a pattern of synchronized movements where partners exchange positions within the circle formation.
thattadavu 3: A foot-tapping pattern that introduces triple taps. The dancer taps each foot three times in succession before alternating to the other foot. This creates a complex rhythmic pattern while maintaining the basic half-sitting position. To identify this movement, look for the triple-tapping action on each foot before changing to the other side.
reach-in foul: A personal foul called when a defender illegally uses their hand or arm to reach in and impede an opponent's movement or to steal the ball. Look for the defender's hand making contact with the offensive player's body or arm.
roasting: A dry-heat cooking method where food is cooked uncovered in an oven with hot air circulating around it. This creates browning on the exterior while cooking the interior, enhancing flavors through caramelization. Look for the even browning around the entire surface of the food.
whip stitch: A simple over-edge stitch used for joining two pieces of fabric or securing edges. The needle passes over the edge and into both fabric layers at an angle, creating diagonal stitches. Look for diagonal stitches visible on the edge that wrap around it, commonly used for appliqué, closing stuffed items, or securing fabric edges together.
thattadavu 6: A foot-tapping pattern with emphasis on the sixth beat. The dancer taps each foot in a pattern where the sixth tap receives special emphasis, often with a slight pause afterward. This creates a distinctive rhythmic quality that differentiates it from other variations. To identify this movement, look for the emphasized sixth beat in each sequence, often followed by a momentary pause.
highwayman's hitch: A quick-release hitch that can be tied and untied with a simple pull on the working end, even under tension. Look for the characteristic loop structure that releases instantly when the end is pulled. This knot is designed for situations where quick release may be necessary, though it sacrifices security.
shell stitch: A decorative pattern where multiple stitches (usually 5-7 double crochets) are worked into a single stitch, creating a fan or shell shape. The next shell is typically separated by a space or single stitch. Look for the fan-shaped groups of stitches that spread out from a single point.
penguin catches: A specialized catch where the arm is extended downward and twisted so the hand points outward with the palm facing up, resembling a penguin's flipper. The ball is caught in this awkward hand position. Look for the distinctive arm position with palm facing upward and outward.
point cutting: Cutting into the ends of the hair with scissor tips held vertically or slightly angled to the section, creating texture and softening blunt lines by snipping small notches. Look for: scissor tips pointing upwards into the hair ends, making small, subtle cuts into the edge.
back essence: A fundamental tap step where the dancer shifts weight backward while creating rhythmic patterns with the feet. The dancer alternates brushing the foot backward, stepping, and shifting weight. Look for the continuous backward movement pattern with a distinctive heel-toe rhythm. This differs from Front Essence by moving backward rather than forward.
elevator: Trick involving making the spinning yo-yo climb vertically up the string by pulling a loop upward beneath it. Visually appears like the yo-yo is smoothly ascending an elevator shaft vertically along the string. Different from normal returns as it uses manual lifting rather than automatic yo-yo response.
gainer: A unique flip where the practitioner moves forward while performing a backflip rotation, creating the illusion of gaining ground while flipping backward. Look for the forward motion combined with backward rotation.
oblique cut: A diagonal cutting technique where food (typically cylindrical vegetables) is sliced at an angle, creating elongated oval pieces. Also called a "roll cut," it involves cutting at an angle, then rotating the food between cuts. Look for the elongated, angular slices that provide more surface area for cooking.
horse-collar tackle: A penalty where a defender tackles a ball carrier by grabbing the inside back collar of their jersey or shoulder pads and pulling them down. Look for a defender's hand inside the back of a runner's jersey/collar with a sudden backward pull.
copa: A move also known as "in and out," where from a cross-hand hold (left over right), the lead creates an extension then pulls the follow in with the right hand while leading the left hand over the follow's head, causing a 180° turn to the left. The follow is then pushed back out and completes another half left turn to return to facing the lead. Look for the characteristic in-and-out motion with the crossed hand position.
ufo: A trick where the yo-yo is thrown at an angled, horizontal spin, creating a distinct sideways orientation resembling a spinning flying saucer or UFO. Visually unique due to the horizontal spin plane and often accompanied by a characteristic buzzing sound from the spinning yo-yo. Distinguished from vertical spin throws (Sleeper or Throw Down) by its horizontal axis and spin orientation, often used to adjust string tension.
wrist shot: A shot where the player uses primarily wrist motion to propel the puck forward. This accurate shot allows for better puck control and quick release but generally has less power than a slap shot.
double-fold hem: A clean finishing technique where the raw edge is folded twice and then stitched down, completely encasing the raw edge inside the folds. The fabric edge is first folded under once, then folded again before stitching to prevent fraying. Look for a completely enclosed edge with no raw edges visible, creating a clean, professional finish.
releadering cut / reduction cut: Pruning a branch by cutting it back to a significant side branch (lateral), which then becomes the new main growing point for that limb. Look for: a person cutting a larger branch just past where a smaller side branch grows out, leaving the side branch intact.
man on trapeze: A fundamental sidestyle mount achieved by throwing a horizontal Breakaway and catching the yo-yo on the horizontal string segment between both hands. Visually distinct by appearing like an acrobat (the yo-yo) balanced securely on a tightrope (the string). This mount serves as a foundation for many advanced tricks, setting it apart from simple catches or loops due to the sustained string balance position.
midshipman's hitch: A sliding hitch similar to the taut-line hitch, used to create an adjustable loop in a line under tension. Look for the series of turns around the standing part that allow the knot to grip while remaining adjustable by hand. This hitch is useful for adjustable tension situations.
twist lift: A pairs move where the male partner lifts the female over his head and tosses her in the air. While airborne, the female partner twists. The man then catches his partner and places her back on the ice.
myoclonic seizure: A brief, involuntary, shock-like muscle jerk or twitch typically lasting less than a second. Myoclonic seizures appear randomly or in clusters and frequently occur in the upper body or arms. They often resemble the common experience of sudden muscle jerks occurring while falling asleep, but when they occur frequently or disruptively during awake periods, they indicate an underlying neurological abnormality or seizure disorder.
paysanne: A knife cutting technique that creates thin, flat squares or slightly rectangular pieces, often following the natural shape of the vegetable. Typically about 1/2 inch square and 1/8 inch thick, this cut is used for soups and stews. Look for the thin, tile-like pieces that cook evenly.
left turn: A counterclockwise rotation where the dancer turns to their left, typically a 360-degree turn. It can be used by both leads and follows, either on its own or taking turns with a partner. Look for the counterclockwise spinning motion, which is less common than right turns in salsa.
flat-felled seam: A strong, durable seam where one seam allowance is trimmed, the other folded over it, and both are topstitched flat to the fabric. All raw edges are enclosed within the seam, creating a clean finish on both sides with two parallel rows of visible stitches. Look for two parallel lines of stitching visible from the right side, commonly used on jeans, especially at inseams.
gathering knot: A binding knot used to gather or bunch material together, such as fabric curtains or rope coils. Look for the knot's ability to cinch and hold material together while maintaining an attractive appearance. This is both a functional and decorative knot.
spirit bomb: A complex trick beginning from a wrist-mounted triangle configuration. The player pops the yo-yo upwards twice, maneuvering it through tight triangle string gaps midair. Visually impressive due to aerial pops and crossing-arm movements, distinctively creating and resolving intricate triangle patterns in midair.
heaving line knot: A weighted knot tied at the end of a light line to allow it to be thrown accurately over a distance. Look for the bulky knot structure designed to add weight for throwing. This specialized knot helps in transferring lines between ships or across gaps.
front flip: A forward somersault where the practitioner jumps up and rotates forward, tucking their knees to their chest before landing on their feet. Look for the forward rotation with the performer's face facing the ground mid-flip.
punching bag: A rapid-fire 2A looping trick in which the yo-yo performs small, fast, inward-facing loops directly in front of the player's fists. Visually resembling quick, short jabs into the air, distinctively faster and tighter loops compared to standard larger loops. Differentiated from other looping styles due to the inward loop direction and tight circles.
cha\u00een\u00e9s: A series of quick, linked turns performed on both feet in succession. The dancer rotates with feet alternating in a tight first position, traveling in a straight line or circle. The term means "chains" or "links." Look for the rapid succession of turns with the feet moving in tight, quick steps.
simple buried suture: An interrupted stitch placed in deeper tissue layers (below the skin) where the knot is tied and cut deep within the wound so it remains hidden beneath the surface closure. Look for: placing and tying individual stitches within deeper layers of an open wound before the skin is closed over them.
crab stitch / reverse single crochet: A decorative edging technique where single crochet stitches are worked in the opposite direction from normal (right to left for right-handed crocheters, left to right for left-handed crocheters). This creates a twisted, rope-like edge with a distinctive texture that adds a professional finish to projects. The stitch is perfect for borders on blankets, garments, and accessories as it creates a firm edge that helps prevent stretching. Despite its unusual working direction, the stitch itself is formed exactly like a standard single crochet.
speed vault: A fast vault technique where the practitioner uses one hand to guide over an obstacle while maintaining forward momentum. Look for the smooth, quick pass with minimal height.
fingerless thumb around: A thumb around (360-degree rotation around thumb) variant where the rotation is initiated by hand or wrist movement rather than a finger push. The pen still makes a complete circle around the thumb but without direct finger propulsion. Look for the pen circling the thumb with visible hand/wrist motion starting the spin. This differs from regular thumb around by the absence of finger contact to initiate rotation.
stamp: A step where the flat foot is placed firmly on the floor with a weight transfer. The dancer places the entire foot on the floor at once, transferring weight to that foot. Look for the solid placement with the foot remaining on the floor after contact. This differs from a stomp because in a stamp, weight is transferred to the foot.
roughing the kicker: A penalty where a defensive player makes forcible contact with a kicker after the kick. Look for a defender contacting the plant leg of the kicker or hitting the kicker with excessive force.
beating / pounding: Using the side of a loosely closed fist (the ulnar border, near the little finger) to rhythmically strike larger, fleshy muscle areas with moderate force. A form of tapotement (which is... a category of rapid, rhythmic, percussive massage strokes). Look for: therapist repeatedly hitting the client's larger muscles (like back or thighs) with the soft side of their loosely clenched fist.
corkscrew: A transitional move where the dancer twists their body while moving from a standing position to the floor or vice versa. The body follows a spiral-like path as it changes levels. Look for the spiraling body motion while changing from standing to floor level.
deflection: When a player changes the direction of a shot or pass by allowing it to hit their stick or body as it travels toward the net. Effective deflections are difficult for goaltenders to track and adjust to.
carrick bend: A powerful bend knot used for joining two ropes, particularly thicker lines. When properly tied, dressed and set, it creates a symmetrical knot with an attractive woven appearance. Look for the distinctive pattern of interwoven rope segments creating a rectangular grid-like structure. This knot maintains its strength even when wet and can be untied even after heavy loading.
drop kick: A technique where a player drops the ball from their hands and kicks it before it touches the ground (typically done by goalkeepers). Look for the player releasing the ball from hands and striking it before it bounces.
pull shot: A batting shot played to a short delivery around waist height, pulled with a horizontal bat toward the leg side. Look for the back-foot positioning and horizontal bat swing aimed toward mid-wicket.
blocked field goal: A defensive play where a defender prevents a field goal attempt from crossing the goal posts by deflecting or stopping the kicked ball. Look for a defender penetrating the line and getting hands up to block the kick.
flagging: A balance technique where a climber extends a free leg (not on a foothold) outward to counterbalance their body weight, preventing rotation and maintaining stability. There are three types: side flag (leg extended to same side), inside flag (leg crosses in front), and outside flag (leg crosses behind). Look for a leg extended without standing on a hold.
bluntslide: A slide trick where the skater ollie's (jumps with the board) over an obstacle and slides with the tail on the far side of the edge, positioning the back truck over the obstacle (the board extends beyond the edge). Look for the tail making contact with the obstacle while the front truck is lifted over the edge.
power: A running play where the offensive line blocks straight ahead with a lead blocker (usually a fullback or pulling guard) creating a path. Look for a lead blocker heading through a specific hole with the running back following directly behind.
double turn: A sequence where the dancer makes two consecutive 360-degree turns, typically executing the first turn on counts 1-2-3 and the second turn on counts 5-6-7. In Cuban salsa, these are typically done as two three-step turns, with each three-step turn creating a full 360-degree rotation. Look for two complete rotations performed in sequence within a single eight-count.
swizzling: A mixing technique using a swizzle stick (traditionally a forked branch) that is rotated rapidly between the palms while inserted in a drink. The bartender places the swizzle stick in the drink and quickly rotates it by rubbing their palms together, creating a frothy texture and ensuring thorough mixing while chilling the outer glass.
front loop only (flo): A crochet technique where you insert your hook through only the front loop of a stitch instead of both loops. When looking at the top of a stitch, you'll see a "V" shape - the front loop is the part of the V closest to you. FLO creates a horizontal ridge on the back of your work and produces a stretchier fabric than standard crochet. This technique is often used for decorative texture, creating hinge points for folding fabric (like in amigurumi), or producing distinctive lines in your project.
searing: A high-heat cooking technique that quickly browns the surface of food, usually meat, to create a flavorful crust through caramelization and Maillard reaction. The food is then typically finished with another cooking method. Look for the rapid browning of the exterior without cooking the interior fully.
free kick: A set piece (stopped play restart) awarded after a foul where the opposing players must remain a minimum of 10 yards from the ball. Look for players lining up a wall of defenders before the kick is taken.
layout: A straight body position, often referring to a tumbling flip performed with a completely straight body. In cheerleading stunts, it can also refer to a horizontal position during aerial transitions. Look for the rigid, straight body alignment with no bend at the hips or knees.
foliar feeding: Applying liquid fertilizer directly onto the leaves (foliage) of plants using a spray bottle or garden sprayer. Look for: a person spraying a mist of liquid onto the leaves of plants, wetting the surface.
compound riposte: An offensive action following a parry that involves two or more movements, typically including feints or disengagements. Unlike a simple riposte, which is direct, the compound riposte uses deceptive movements to get around the opponent's attempt to parry the expected direct riposte. Look for multiple blade actions after a successful parry before the final attack lands.
flap: A two-sound step combining a brush and a step. The dancer brushes the ball of the foot forward then immediately steps down on that same foot, transferring weight. Look for the smooth forward brush followed by the weight transfer. This differs from a shuffle because the second action is a step rather than a backward brush.
entrechat: A jumping step where the dancer crosses their legs in the air multiple times before landing. The number after "entrechat" indicates how many times the legs cross (entrechat quatre, entrechat six, etc.). Look for the rapid crossing and uncrossing of the legs during the jump.
green triangle: A distinct string formation shaped like a triangle, visually recognizable with the yo-yo inside a triangular loop. Known for looking like a knot that magically resolves when the yo-yo is popped out correctly.
kams 4 loop combo: A specific combination sequence created by Kam, an influential pen spinning pioneer. This is a predetermined series of tricks performed in a specific order that has become standardized. Look for the distinctive pattern of tricks that defines this particular combo. This differs from other combinations by its specific sequence, historical significance, and recognition in the pen spinning community.
helicopter: A flair bartending move where a bottle or object spins horizontally in the air, rotating like helicopter blades. The bartender imparts a specific type of spin when throwing the object that causes it to rotate on its horizontal axis while airborne, creating a distinctive visual effect before being caught.
long and short stitch: A filling technique that uses straight stitches of alternating lengths to create smooth color transitions and realistic shading. Rows of stitches are worked with the second row starting between the long and short stitches of the previous row. Look for the blend of colors and smooth surface created by the interlocking stitches of varying lengths. This technique is essential for thread painting and creating realistic, shaded areas in embroidery.
crimp: A grip technique for small edges where the fingers are bent at the second joint with fingertips pressed onto a thin hold. In a "full crimp," the thumb is wrapped over the index finger for additional strength, while a "half crimp" keeps fingers at about 90 degrees without the thumb assist. Look for bent fingers pressing downward on a thin edge with visible tension.
reverse brent stole: A variation of the "Brent Stole" slack trick where the slack loop is whipped in the opposite direction, instantly forming a reversed "Green Triangle" around the yo-yo. Visually similar to Brent Stole, but distinguished by the opposite orientation of the resulting string triangle and the direction of the slack whip.
chorea: A movement disorder characterized by involuntary, irregular, rapid, and spontaneous movements that unpredictably shift from one body location to the next in smooth-like motions. Movements commonly involve muscles of the limbs, torso, or face and are typically worsened by emotional stress, excitement, or intentional movements, yet usually disappear during sleep. Chorea interferes significantly with daily functions and commonly arises in conditions like Huntington’s disease, autoimmune disorders, metabolic imbalances, or as side-effects of medications.
push-up: Starting in a high plank position (body straight, supported on hands and toes), lowering the entire body towards the floor by bending the elbows, keeping the body rigid, then pushing back up until arms are straight. Look for: a person lowering and raising their straight body using only arm strength while facing the floor.
square knot: Also known as the reef knot, this is a binding knot used to join two ends of a single line to secure something. Look for the symmetrical formation with the working ends emerging on opposite sides parallel to the standing parts. While common, this knot is not suitable for critical applications as it can slip under load.
shuffle: A two-sound step consisting of a forward brush followed by a backward brush (spank) with the same foot. The dancer brushes the ball of the foot forward and then immediately brushes it backward. Look for the quick forward-backward brush movement without weight transfer. This differs from a flap because there's no weight transfer in the second action.
focal onset aware seizure: A seizure that begins in a localized portion of the brain, where the person maintains full consciousness and awareness throughout the episode. Although aware, the affected person cannot voluntarily control symptoms including abnormal sensations, unusual smells or tastes, visual disturbances, involuntary jerking or movements confined to one body area, or emotional experiences such as unexplained fear or joy. Typically, the person vividly remembers the event afterward, allowing them to describe the symptoms clearly.
double suicide: Advanced trick where two loops of string are released mid-air simultaneously and caught again. Visually striking as two loops open simultaneously mid-air, briefly resembling juggling. Distinguished from simpler Suicide by the dual-loop release and catch.
rabona: A technique where a player wraps their kicking leg behind their standing leg to strike the ball (used when a player is off-balance or to disguise the direction of play). Look for the crossing of legs when striking the ball.
brush: A basic tap technique where the ball of the foot strikes the floor in a forward motion. The dancer sweeps the ball of the foot against the floor, creating a single sound. Look for the foot starting behind the body and sweeping forward. This differs from a scuff, which uses the heel rather than the ball of the foot.
finger coiling: Twisting small sections of damp curly or coily hair tightly around a finger from root to tip, usually with styling product, to define individual curls or coils. Look for: a person wrapping small strands of wet hair around their index finger, forming a coil.
parkinsonian tremor: A resting tremor typically occurring in people with Parkinson's disease, characterized by rhythmic involuntary shaking occurring mainly when limbs are relaxed and at rest. It primarily affects hands or fingers, appearing as a steady back-and-forth movement, often described as a "pill-rolling" tremor. The tremor generally decreases or stops during voluntary movements or actions.
saut\u00e9ing: A cooking method where food is cooked quickly in a small amount of fat over relatively high heat, typically in a shallow pan. The food is usually cut into small, uniform pieces to ensure even cooking. Look for the rapid cooking in a small amount of oil with frequent movement of the food.
quad flip: A flip jump with four rotations in the air. Look for the inside edge takeoff with toe pick assistance.
block: A defensive move where a player legally deflects or stops an opponent's shot attempt before it reaches the basket. Look for the defender's hand making contact with the ball while it's still in the shooter's hands or in the air.
steppage gait: An unusual walking style characterized by exaggerated lifting of the knee and foot, commonly caused when an individual cannot properly raise their foot upward due to muscle weakness or nerve damage. The gait resembles climbing stairs ("stepping"), leading to a distinctive walking appearance and increased risk of stumbling or falling.
crown knot: A knot tied in the strands at the end of a rope, typically used as the starting point for a back splice or other end finishing techniques. Look for the strands crossing over each other to form a crown-like pattern. This knot helps prevent a rope's end from unraveling and creates a decorative finish.
throw off the hump: A pottery wheel technique where multiple vessels are thrown from a single large piece of clay without removing the entire mass from the wheel. The potter centers a large mound of clay, forms a vessel at the top portion, cuts it off, then continues with the remaining clay to make additional pieces. Look for the efficient production of multiple similarly-sized vessels from one clay mound.
stiff arm: An offensive move where a ball carrier uses an extended arm to push away a would-be tackler. Look for a runner extending their arm straight out to push a defender's upper body or helmet.
taking the temperature: A technique used to determine the doneness of food, particularly meat, by inserting a thermometer into the thickest part to measure the internal temperature. This ensures food safety and desired doneness without relying solely on visual cues or timing. Look for the use of meat thermometers, instant-read thermometers, or digital probe thermometers to check if food has reached a safe or optimal temperature.
twist basket toss: A basket toss where the flyer performs a twisting rotation in the air before being caught. The number of twists can vary (full twist, double twist, etc.). Look for the vertical toss with spinning motion along the body's vertical axis.
hip check: A body checking technique where a player uses their hip and lower body to upend an opponent. When executed properly, the player drops to a low stance and drives their hip into the opponent's thigh area.
intentional grounding: A penalty where a quarterback throws a pass with no realistic chance of completion to avoid a loss of yardage. Look for a quarterback throwing the ball away with no receiver in the area while under pressure.
shuvit: A trick where the board rotates 180 degrees horizontally (which means spinning flat like a frisbee) under the skater's feet without the tail hitting the ground. Look for the board spinning parallel to the ground without flipping vertically.
double / double-hit: In épée, when both fencers hit each other within 40-50 milliseconds, resulting in both receiving a point. In foil and sabre, this can occur when priority is not clearly established, resulting in a call of "simultaneous actions" with no point awarded. Look for both fencers' scoring lights illuminating together.
chop block: A penalty where one player blocks an opponent at or below the knees while the opponent is engaged with another blocker. Look for two offensive players blocking one defender with one going high and one going low.
ashley's bend: A bend knot used to securely join the ends of two ropes together. It consists of two interlocking overhand knots with the ends threaded through the center in a specific pattern. Look for the distinctive pattern of interlocking loops with ends carefully positioned adjacent to each other. This knot tends to jam under heavy loads, making it difficult or impossible to untie afterward.
sleeper: The fundamental yo-yo trick involving throwing the yo-yo straight down, allowing it to spin freely at the end of the string without returning immediately. Visually recognized simply as the yo-yo spinning quietly at the bottom of the string. This stationary spinning clearly distinguishes it from immediate-return throws.
double stepover: A skill move where a player moves their foot around the ball twice in circular motions without touching it (to confuse defenders) before accelerating away. Look for the two consecutive circular foot movements over the ball.
floater: A high-arcing shot taken on the move, usually in the lane, designed to go over taller defenders. Look for the exaggerated arc of the ball as it's released.
cone down: A centering technique in wheel throwing where a cone-shaped mound of clay is pressed downward to create a flattened, compact disc of clay. After raising the clay into a cone shape, the potter applies downward pressure with their hands to compress the clay and eliminate air pockets. Look for the transformation from a tall cone to a lower, wider form.
stop and go: A skill move where a player suddenly stops with the ball, causing the defender to also stop, then quickly accelerates again (catching the defender off-balance). Look for the sudden pause followed by acceleration.
drop shot: A soft touch shot that barely clears the net and bounces very little, designed to catch an opponent off-guard who is positioned deep in the court. Play in which the player hits the ball lightly enough to just go over the net, usually with backspin. Look for minimal pace and quick bounces near the net.
leg glance: A delicate batting shot played to a ball aimed at leg stump, where the batsman uses fine wrist work to glance the ball toward the fine leg area. Look for subtle angling of the bat face and minimal power application.
360 shuvit: A shuvit (horizontal board rotation) where the board rotates a full 360 degrees horizontally (a complete circle parallel to the ground). Look for the complete rotation of the board under the skater's feet.
opening the clay: The process of creating the initial hollow in a centered mound of clay on the pottery wheel. The potter presses thumbs or fingers into the center of the clay to establish the interior space that will become the vessel. Look for the transformation from a solid clay mound to a vessel with walls and a bottom.
quad axel: An axel jump with four and a half rotations in the air. Look for the forward takeoff characteristic of all axel jumps, followed by 4.5 rotations before landing.
zulu spin: A footwork move where the dancer spins in a squatting position using their hands and feet for support and momentum. The rotation happens with one leg extended while pivoting on the other foot. Look for the spinning motion in a low squat position with leg extension.
crimping: A decorative technique used to seal and finish the edges of pies, tarts, and other pastries by pinching or pressing the dough into a pattern. This not only creates an attractive edge but also helps secure the filling inside. Look for the distinctive wavy or pinched pattern around the edge of the pastry.
burden stitch: A filling stitch that uses rows of parallel straight stitches to cover an area, with each row offset by half the stitch length to create a cohesive texture. The stitch was named after Elizabeth Burden who taught at the Royal School of Needlework in the 1870s. Look for evenly spaced parallel lines that create a smooth, textured surface. This stitch is particularly effective for portraying natural textures in crewel embroidery, such as terrain hummocks or hills.
boarding: A penalty that occurs when a player checks an opponent violently into the boards when they are in a vulnerable position. This dangerous action typically results in a minor or major penalty depending on severity.
triangle pass: A trick where the pen moves between three points (typically thumb and two fingers) creating a triangular pattern, with the pen balancing on top of the three contact points and rotating between them. Look for the pen traveling in a triangular path between three supporting digits. This differs from finger pass by the triangular route rather than linear progression across fingers.
relev\u00e9: A rising movement where the dancer rises from a flat foot position to demi-pointe (balls of the feet) or pointe (tips of the toes for women in pointe shoes). Look for the lifting of the heels off the floor while maintaining alignment and turnout.
barn door: An uncontrolled rotation away from the rock that occurs when your body weight shifts too far to one side, causing you to swing off the wall like a door opening. This happens when you have only two points of contact on one side of your body, creating an axis that you can pivot around. Look for a climber suddenly swinging away from the wall when they release a handhold.
mulching: Spreading a layer of material (such as wood chips, straw, bark, or gravel) over the surface of the soil around plants. Look for: a person applying a distinct layer of material onto the ground around plants, covering the bare soil.
through ball: A forward pass played into space behind the defensive line for a teammate to run onto (breaking the defensive line). Look for the pass going between or behind defenders into open space.
double clutch dunk: A dunk where the player pulls the ball down or back after initially extending it towards the rim, then extends it again before finishing the dunk. Look for the distinct double motion of the arms during the dunk.
temps lev\u00e9: A hop on one foot where the other foot is held in a specific position in the air. The term means "time lifted." Look for the suspended moment when one foot is lifted while hopping on the supporting leg.
caramelizing: The process of heating sugars (either pure sugar or naturally occurring in foods like onions) until they break down and turn golden brown, developing complex flavors. This creates rich, sweet notes and changes the texture of the food. Look for the transformation from light to golden-brown color and the development of sweet, nutty aromas.
scissor over comb: Cutting hair using scissors that move along the surface of a comb, where the comb lifts the hair from the scalp and determines the cutting length and angle, used for blending and short cuts. Look for: scissors continuously snipping hair that is being lifted and held by a comb close to the head.
mooring hitch: A temporary, quick-release hitch used for securing a vessel to a dock or mooring post. Look for the characteristic loop structure that holds securely under tension but can be quickly released with a pull of the working end. This specialized nautical knot prioritizes quick release capability.
triple time step: An extension of the single time step with additional sounds between the shuffle and ball change. The dancer performs a shuffle, hop, shuffle-step, tap, and ball change. Look for the more complex sound pattern compared to the single time step. This differs from the single and double time steps by having more sounds in the middle section.
wiper: A utilitarian trick where the pen moves side-to-side in a pendulum motion, typically used as a connecting element between other tricks. The pen oscillates horizontally like a windshield wiper. Look for the lateral back-and-forth movement without significant rotation. This differs from other tricks by its horizontal swinging motion rather than rotational or vertical movement.
rock to fakie: A transition trick (which is performed on curved ramps) where the skater approaches a quarter pipe or coping (the metal edge at the top of a ramp), places the front trucks over the lip, rocks forward slightly, then returns back down the ramp riding fakie (backward). Look for the momentary pause at the top.
around the world: A classic trick involving throwing the yo-yo forward and allowing it to loop around in a full vertical circle. Visually recognizable by the yo-yo traveling in a complete 360-degree circular path overhead, similar to spinning a lasso. It differs from other looping tricks by the large, vertical, overhead circle it forms.
icicle hitch: A specialized hitch designed to grip effectively on tapered objects like posts, particularly when the pull is parallel to the object in a specific direction. Look for the multiple wraps that enhance grip on the tapered surface. This knot is valuable when standard hitches would slip on a conical or tapered object.
pull cut: A foundational whittling technique where the knife is pulled toward the body, similar to peeling a vegetable. The blade is held against the wood and drawn toward the thumb of the hand holding the wood, removing thin shavings with each stroke. This cut is ideal for precise shaping and detail work, but requires protective equipment like thumb guards since the blade moves toward your body. Visual identification: Look for the carver drawing the knife toward themselves while taking off thin shavings of wood.
renvers\u00e9: A turning movement where the dancer's balance appears to be upset by the inclination of the body. The body bends from the waist during the turn, typically sideways and backward. Look for the tilted, "knocked off balance" appearance that gives this step its name.
sissonne: A jump that takes off from both feet and usually lands on one foot (though some variations land on both). The legs separate in the air, creating a scissor-like effect. Look for the separation of the legs in the air and the distinctive take-off from both feet.
paddle down: A goaltending technique where the goaltender places the wide portion of their stick (the paddle) flat on the ice to block shots or passes through the crease area. Effective for stopping passes across the goal mouth.
the weave: A pattern where balls are "woven" through each other, creating an intricate crossing pattern. The balls follow paths that intersect and weave around each other like threads in fabric. Look for the complex interlacing pattern created by the balls' trajectories.
prick stitch: A precise stitch used in fine hand sewing for creating almost invisible seams, particularly in tailoring. The needle picks up only a thread or two from the fabric on each side of the seam, creating tiny, evenly spaced stitches. Look for the extremely small, regular stitches that are barely visible on the right side of the work. This stitch is used for attaching linings, facings, or in places where very precise, strong but invisible stitching is required.
double or nothing: Fundamental mount where the yo-yo loops twice around fingers on both hands, ending on a double-layered string formation. Visually identified by extra loops around fingers, creating complexity beyond a basic Trapeze.
double trapeze: Trick where the yo-yo loops twice around the player's finger, landing onto double strings in a trapeze formation. Visually notable as the yo-yo rests on two parallel strands, unlike a regular trapeze’s single strand.
back post double crochet (bpdc): A variation of the double crochet where you insert your hook from the back side of your work around the post (vertical part) of a stitch in the previous row, rather than through the top loops. This creates a raised ridge on the back side of the fabric and a recessed area on the front. Look for the distinct raised texture created on the reverse side of the work.
the shower: A classic pattern where balls follow a circular path, with one hand making high arcing throws to the other hand, which makes quick horizontal returns. This is often what non-jugglers attempt first. Look for the distinctive circular pattern with high throws from one hand.
bombershay: A step involving a heel dig, followed by a brush, and completed with a step. The dancer presses the heel into the floor, brushes the foot forward, and transfers weight onto that foot. Look for the distinctive heel-toe-step pattern with a slight diagonal movement. This differs from similar steps by the specific heel-dig to brush combination.
boingy boing: A trick where the yo-yo repeatedly bounces between two parallel strings held taut between the player’s hands. Visually looks like a yo-yo rapidly bouncing or "boinging" vertically back and forth like a piston between strings. Distinct from other tricks due to its unique bouncing vertical motion.
face mask: A penalty where a player grabs and pulls an opponent's face mask. Look for a player's head being visibly turned or pulled by an opponent grabbing the front of their helmet.
dyno: A dynamic jumping movement where a climber launches completely off the wall with both feet leaving their holds, using momentum to reach a distant hold that cannot be reached statically. The climber's body becomes briefly airborne during the move. Look for a climber completely leaving the wall mid-air while jumping for a hold.
crawl: A gliding movement where the feet slide along the floor without leaving the surface. The dancer pushes off one leg and allows both feet to glide, with the front foot's back edge of the heel touching the floor during the motion. Look for the smooth, controlled sliding motion with both feet maintaining contact with the floor. This differs from other traveling steps by the continuous floor contact.
soloham: An advanced 4A (offstring) category involving two offstring yo-yos being manipulated simultaneously, creating complex aerial interactions. Visually resembles juggling, with two unattached yo-yos flying and being caught rhythmically on separate strings, clearly distinct from single-yo-yo offstring routines due to the coordination required.
spanish bowline: A double-loop variation of the bowline that creates two fixed loops. Used for rescue operations where a person needs support under both arms or legs. Look for the two equal loops with the characteristic bowline structure. This specialized rescue knot provides balanced support.
twisted sonic reverse: A twisted sonic (1.5 rotation transfer using charge-pass combination) performed in the opposite direction from normal, with reverse rotation while transferring between slots. Look for the 1.5 rotation pattern going backward between finger positions. This differs from regular twisted sonic only in the direction of movement and spin.
fake double: A trick that creates the illusion of a double rotation by smoothly linking a vertical thumb around (360-degree rotation around thumb) with an index around (360-degree rotation around index finger). The pen performs these two distinct spins so fluidly they appear as one continuous movement. Look for two consecutive around rotations executed without visible pause. This differs from a true double around by using two different fingers for the rotations.
split jump: A jump where the skater creates a straddle position, forming a V with their legs. Look for the legs to separate into a full split position in the air.
50-50 grind: A grind trick (which is when the metal trucks of the skateboard scrape along an object) where the skater rides with both trucks (the metal axles that hold the wheels) grinding along an edge, rail or curb. Look for both the front and back trucks making contact with the obstacle being grinded.
bump: A technique where a bottle or shaker is bounced off a part of the body (typically the forearm, elbow, or shoulder) to continue its spin or change direction. The controlled impact adds momentum to the spinning object and allows the bartender to redirect it for the next move, with skilled practitioners capable of executing multiple consecutive bumps.
volley: A technique where a player strikes the ball in mid-air before it touches the ground (requires timing and technical skill). Look for the player connecting with the ball while it's still in the air.
effleurage: Long, smooth, gliding strokes applied with relaxed palms, fingers, thumbs, or forearms, moving along the contours of the body. Often used to apply oil/lotion, warm tissues, assess the area, and transition between other strokes. Look for: therapist sliding their hands or forearms smoothly and continuously over the skin, covering significant length with consistent pressure.
triple axel: An axel jump with three and a half rotations in the air. Look for the forward takeoff characteristic of all axel jumps.
ollie: A fundamental aerial trick (which means getting the board off the ground) where the skater pops the tail on the ground (pressing down on the back of the board) while sliding the front foot forward to level the board, allowing both skater and board to become airborne (leave the ground). Look for the distinctive pop-slide-jump motion.
high sticking: A penalty called when a player carries their stick above the normal height of the shoulders and makes contact with an opponent. It can also refer to playing the puck with a stick above the crossbar height.
rail precision: A precision jump specifically targeted at landing on a narrow rail or similar object, requiring exact foot placement. Look for the precise landing on a thin surface.
trimming: The process of refining the shape and removing excess clay from a leather-hard thrown pot after it has had time to dry partially. The pot is inverted and reattached to the wheel, then tools are used to carve away clay, create foot rings, and refine the overall form. Look for the refined base, even wall thickness, and intentionally shaped exterior of the vessel.
backhand shot: A shot taken using the back side of the hockey stick blade. Though less powerful than forehand shots, backhand shots can be deceptive to goaltenders because they are harder to read and anticipate.
snap shot: A shot combining elements of both wrist shots and slap shots. The player does not wind up as far as in a slap shot but generates more power than a wrist shot by snapping the wrists while maintaining accuracy.
423: A three-ball pattern in siteswap notation where the balls follow a specific sequence creating a rhythm of "right-pause-right-left-pause-left." Two balls stay on their respective sides (the "4"s) while one crosses between hands (the "3"). Look for the characteristic rhythm with pauses between same-hand throws.
layback spin: A spin where the skater spins while leaning backward with an arched back, often with one leg extended backward. Look for the distinctive arched upper body position with the head tilted back.
tackle for loss: A defensive play where a ball carrier is tackled behind the line of scrimmage. Look for a ball carrier being brought down behind the original line of scrimmage, resulting in negative yardage.
handstand: A fundamental skill where the athlete balances on their hands with the body inverted vertically, arms straight next to the ears. Look for the perfectly straight body line from hands to pointed toes with no arch or pike in the body.
broadcasting seed: Sowing seeds (which is... planting them) by scattering them by hand with a sweeping motion or using a mechanical spreader device over prepared soil. Look for: a person throwing seeds widely across the ground or using a wheeled/hand-cranked device distributing small particles.
chain: The most basic crochet element formed by pulling yarn through a loop on your hook repeatedly. Chains create the foundation for most crochet projects and can be used to create height at the beginning of rows. Look for the simple, linked appearance that resembles a series of connected "V" shapes.
point-in-line: A defensive position where the fencer extends their arm and weapon directly toward the opponent with the point threatening the valid target. A properly established point-in-line has priority in foil and sabre, meaning the opponent must remove the blade before attacking. Look for the fully extended arm with the point aimed directly at the opponent from out of attacking range.
table top: This can refer to either: 1) A jump where the cheerleader appears to be sitting in the air with legs bent at 90 degrees (also called Double Hook), or 2) An arm motion where both arms are bent at 90 degrees with fists pointing down (also called daggers). Look for either the seated position in the air or the bent-arm position at chest level.
swing: A bowling technique where the ball curves in the air before reaching the batsman. Look for movement of the ball through the air rather than off the pitch, due to asymmetric air pressure created by the seam position.
essential tremor: A common involuntary rhythmic shaking predominantly affecting the hands, particularly noticeable during voluntary movements such as writing, eating, drinking, or performing tasks requiring precision. Less commonly, essential tremor also appears in the head, voice, or other body parts. Unlike other tremors, it often improves temporarily after consuming small amounts of alcohol and can run within families without an identified underlying neurological illness.
sonic rise: A sonic variation where the pen moves upward through multiple finger slots in a sequential pattern, creating an ascending effect. Look for the pen traveling upward through consecutive finger positions using sonic-style conical motion. This differs from regular sonic by moving through multiple slots in an upward sequence rather than just one transfer.
smash: An overhead shot hit with full power, typically used to finish points against lobs. A hard, serve-like shot hit over the player's head. Look for the overhead motion similar to a serve, with the player jumping to hit a high ball.
deadpoint: A controlled dynamic movement where a climber times their reach for a hold at the precise moment when upward momentum stops but downward momentum hasn't yet begun—the "dead point" of the motion. Unlike a dyno, at least one foot typically remains in contact with the wall. Look for a climber reaching for a hold at the apex of their movement.
knuckleball: A technique where a player strikes the ball with minimal spin, causing it to move unpredictably in the air (difficult for goalkeepers to track). Look for the ball swerving and dipping in flight.
rimming: The technique of decorating the rim of a glass with salt, sugar, or other flavorings. The bartender first moistens the rim by running a citrus wedge around it, then dips or rolls the edge in the chosen substance, creating a decorative and flavorful border that enhances both the appearance and taste of the cocktail.
front post double crochet (fpdc): Similar to BPDC but worked from the front of the fabric. You insert your hook from the front side around the post of a stitch, creating a raised ridge on the front of the work. Look for the pronounced vertical ridges that stand out from the front surface of the crocheted fabric.
brunoise: A knife cutting technique that produces very small, precise cubes measuring approximately 1/8 inch (3mm) on each side. It starts with julienne cuts that are then diced crosswise. This fine dice is used for soups, sauces, and garnishes where uniform cooking and appearance are important. Look for tiny, perfectly uniform cubes.
knee slide celebration: A goal celebration where a player slides on their knees across the field (often toward the corner flag or supporters). Look for the player dropping to their knees and sliding after scoring.
mills mess: A famous pattern created by Steve Mills where the arms cross and uncross while the balls move in a side-to-side flow. The balls follow a figure-eight pattern with throws made from near the center of the body. Look for the characteristic arm-crossing movement and side-to-side ball flow.
fingerless thumbaround reverse: Same as fingerless thumb around (pen rotating around thumb without finger push) but with the pen rotating in the opposite direction (clockwise for right-handed spinners instead of counterclockwise). Look for the backward rotation around the thumb initiated by hand/wrist movement. This differs from regular fingerless thumb around only in the direction of rotation.
jade whip: Elegant whip trick with slack string whipped gently from the front around the yo-yo. Visually flowing, smoother than Iron Whip.
goaltending: A violation called when a defender touches the ball on its downward arc to the basket, when it's above the rim, or when it's touching the backboard (if it has a chance to go in). Look for the referee's signal after a defender interferes with a shot near the rim.
head cut: In sabre fencing, a downward cutting action aimed at the opponent's head, which is part of the valid target area. The cut is made with the edge of the blade in a sweeping motion from high to low. Look for the distinct overhead cutting motion directed at the top of the opponent's mask.
kick serve: A serve with heavy topspin that causes the ball to bounce high, making it jump up toward the receiver's shoulder level. A large amount of topspin is applied by hitting up on the ball and snapping the wrist. Look for the high bounce that makes the ball kick up after landing.
tilling: Breaking up and churning the soil using tools like a shovel or fork, or a motorized machine (rototiller), to loosen it for planting. Look for: a person repeatedly digging and turning soil over an area, or operating a machine with rotating blades that digs into the ground.
hara massage: A form of massage focused specifically on the abdomen (hara is Japanese for abdomen). Techniques often involve gentle palming, circular motions, and specific finger pressure applied systematically to the belly region. Look for: therapist performing various massage techniques exclusively on the client's stomach/abdominal area.
clipping: A penalty where a player blocks an opponent by hitting them from behind at or below the waist. Look for a blocker diving at the back of a defender's legs.
staking: Inserting a stake (a wood, bamboo, metal, or plastic post) into the ground near a plant and loosely tying the plant's stem to the stake for support. Look for: a person pushing a post into the ground next to a plant and attaching the stem to it with ties.
burke's barrage: A three-ball pattern invented by Ken Burke where one ball is carried through a circular motion while the other balls follow a criss-crossing path. It involves throwing one ball (the "4") under the arm while crossed, carrying another ball (the "3") through the pattern, and often using claw catches. Look for the arms crossing and uncrossing with one ball being carried around.
bobble stitch: A dimensional stitch created by working several incomplete double crochets (usually 3-5) into the same stitch and then completing them together by pulling through all remaining loops. This creates a protruding ball-like texture on the fabric. Look for rounded bumps that project prominently from the surface of the work.
nattadavu 2: A stretching movement similar to Nattadavu 1 but with a continuous flowing quality. The dancer extends the legs to the sides alternately while maintaining balance, with a different rhythm and execution from the first variation. The movement flows more continuously without pauses between leg extensions. To identify this movement, look for the smooth, uninterrupted alternating leg extensions with more fluidity than Nattadavu 1.
slower ball: A variation delivery from a pace bowler that is deliberately bowled at a reduced speed to deceive the batsman. Look for a change in the bowler's grip or action and the ball traveling noticeably slower than usual.
holding: A penalty called when a player grabs an opponent's body, equipment, or stick with their hands to impede their movement. This interference prevents the opponent from full participation in the play.
behind-the-back pass: A passing technique where the player moves the ball behind their back before releasing it to a teammate, used to deceive defenders by hiding the direction of the pass. Look for the ball going behind the passer's body before reaching the receiver.
interception: A defensive action where a player cuts off or stops a pass between opposing players (regaining possession). Look for a defender anticipating and stepping into the path of a pass.
grand jet\u00e9: A large, traveling jump where the dancer leaps from one foot to the other, with legs extended in a split position in mid-air. One of the most spectacular jumps in ballet. Look for the dramatic split in the air and the impression of flight.
pas de chat: A "step of the cat" where the dancer jumps sideways with both feet leaving the ground, knees bent and drawn up toward the chest one after the other in mid-air. Look for the cat-like quality as the legs bend up in succession rather than simultaneously.
quad lutz: A lutz jump with four rotations in the air. Look for the deep outside edge takeoff with toe pick assistance.
trivela: A technique where a player strikes the ball with the outside of their foot, creating swerve or curve (often used for crosses or shots). Look for the unique outside-of-foot contact with the ball.
forward pass: Basic trick involving a horizontal forward throw and immediate return of the yo-yo. Visually resembles a straightforward horizontal toss forward and quick catch, unlike a Sleeper, which stays spinning.
vacilala: A hands-free turn in Cuban salsa similar to a right turn but performed without holding hands. It's often used when dancing apart and can lead into shines like the Suzy Q. Look for the right turn executed without hand connection between partners.
jet sweep: An offensive play where a receiver in motion receives a handoff or pitch running horizontally across the formation. Look for a receiver at full speed taking a handoff or pitch while crossing in front of the quarterback.
time warp: A looping trick involving performing an "Around the World" loop in one direction immediately followed by reversing the loop in the opposite direction without pause. Visually noticeable due to the sudden change in looping direction mid-motion, creating the illusion of reversing time or motion direction abruptly. Distinguished from basic looping tricks by this distinct directional reversal mid-sequence.
bluelien rolls: A two-handed string trick (3A) where two yo-yos roll around each other in alternating patterns. Visually, it looks like two yo-yos weaving over and under each other simultaneously. It differs from simpler rolls by involving two yo-yos actively interacting in a coordinated, symmetrical motion.
creeper: Similar to "Walk the Dog" but performed low to the ground with the player often crouching. Visually appears as if the player is creeping or crawling along behind a yo-yo rolling on the floor. Differs from standard "Walk the Dog" by involving a lower stance and proximity to the ground.
5-0 grind: A grind (which is when the metal trucks scrape along an object) where only the back truck (the metal axle at the back of the board) makes contact with the edge or rail while the front truck is elevated. Look for the angled position with only the rear wheels touching the obstacle.
tic-tac-toe pass: A rapid sequence of two or more quick passes between teammates that leads to a scoring chance. The puck movement resembles the straight lines drawn in the game tic-tac-toe.
honda knot / lasso knot: A sliding loop knot used at the end of a lariat or lasso. It creates a loop that remains open and can be quickly tightened. Look for the fixed eye through which the rope passes to create an adjustable loop. This knot is essential for roping applications.
