squat: Lowering the hips from a standing position by bending the knees and hips, as if sitting back into a chair, keeping the chest up and back straight, then returning to a standing position. Often performed with a barbell across the upper back or holding dumbbells. Look for: a person bending knees and hips deeply, lowering their body towards the ground while staying upright, then standing back up.
hurdle: An offensive move where a ball carrier jumps over a defender attempting to tackle them. Look for a runner clearly leaving the ground and jumping completely over a defender who is low to the ground.
sonic fall: A variation of sonic (conical rotation transfer between finger slots) where the pen moves downward through multiple finger slots in succession, creating a cascading effect. Look for the pen descending through consecutive finger positions with sonic-style conical motion. This differs from regular sonic by moving through multiple slots downward rather than just one upward transfer.
hyperreflexia: An exaggerated reflex response to stimulation. When a medical professional performs a reflex test (for instance, tapping below the knee), the resulting muscle movement is abnormally strong or exaggerated, possibly involving involuntary continuous rhythmic contractions. Hyperreflexia can result from neurological conditions affecting upper motor neurons or pathways in the brain and spinal cord, including cerebral palsy, spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, strokes, or certain metabolic conditions.
hand pollinate: Manually transferring pollen (which is... fine powder containing male reproductive cells) from the anther (male part) to the stigma (female part) inside a flower using a small tool like a brush, swab, or another flower part. Look for: a person carefully touching the inside parts of flowers sequentially with a small, delicate tool.
slice serve: A serve hit with sidespin that curves in the air and after bouncing. The server brushes the back of the ball toward their dominant side. Look for the curved trajectory and sideways bounce.
charging: A penalty that occurs when a player takes more than three strides before checking an opponent or leaves their feet during a body check. This penalty is called to prevent excessively violent collisions.
illegal formation: A penalty where the offense fails to have the required number of players on the line of scrimmage at the snap. Look for fewer than seven offensive players lined up on the line of scrimmage when the ball is snapped.
poke test: A technique to determine if bread dough has properly fermented or proofed by poking it with a floured finger. If the indentation springs back partially but still leaves a small dent, the dough is ready; if it springs back completely, it needs more time. Look for the response of the dough to a gentle poke.
neutral zone infraction: A penalty where a defensive player enters the neutral zone and causes an offensive player to react. Look for a defender jumping into the space between offensive and defensive lines, causing an offensive lineman to move.
scrunch: Gently squeezing sections of damp, wavy or curly hair upwards towards the scalp using cupped hands to enhance curl pattern, add volume, and distribute product. Look for: hands cupping and compressing sections of hair in an upward motion towards the roots.
continuous locking suture: A continuous suture where, before tightening each pass, the needle is passed through the loop of the preceding stitch, creating a more secure, ridged closure. Look for: a continuous line of stitches where each stitch appears to loop around the previous one, creating an overlapping or coiled appearance along the wound edge.
canadian jam knot: Also known as an Arbor Knot, this is a binding knot used for securing bundles or compressing loads. It's often used as a "bushcraft zip tie" to secure rolled items like sleeping bags. Look for a self-tightening loop that applies compression as the standing end is pulled. This knot is simple but effective for bundling and binding applications.
continuous (running) suture: Closing a wound with a single, unbroken strand of suture, starting with a knot at one end and ending with a knot at the other, passing the needle through both wound edges repeatedly along the incision line. Look for: a series of diagonal stitches running along the wound closure, tied only at the very beginning and end.
lemon peel stitch: A simple textured pattern created by alternating single crochet and double crochet stitches across a row, then offsetting them in the next row. The resulting fabric has a nubbly texture resembling lemon peel. Look for the regularly spaced bumps across the surface of the fabric.
thumb around reverse: Same as thumb around (360-degree rotation around thumb) but with the pen rotating in the opposite direction (clockwise for right-handed spinners, counterclockwise for left-handed). Look for the backward rotation around the thumb. This differs from regular thumb around only in the direction of spin.
finger-to-nose test: Assessing coordination and proprioception (which is the sense of the body's position in space) by having the person alternately touch their own nose and the examiner's finger with their index finger, first with eyes open, then sometimes closed. Look for: the person reaching back and forth between their nose and the examiner's finger; note accuracy (hitting the target), smoothness of movement, and whether a tremor appears, especially near the targets.
new york walk: A basic salsa step where partners break apart to the side while maintaining hand connection, then return to face each other. Also sometimes called the "open break" or "side basic step." Look for the side-to-side opening movement with partners maintaining hand connection.
swing step: Also known as a "360 Cross Body Lead" where the lead performs a 360-degree turn while executing a cross body lead. This adds a full rotation to the standard cross body lead pattern. Look for the combination of the cross body lead with a complete rotation.
pop shuvit: A variation of the shuvit where the skater pops the tail (pressing down on the back of the board to make it bounce off the ground) to make the board gain air (get off the ground) while rotating 180 degrees horizontally. Look for the added height compared to a regular shuvit.
nose manual: Similar to a manual but balanced on the front wheels with the back wheels lifted off the ground (like a wheelie but on the front wheels). Look for the back of the skateboard lifted up.
behind-the-back: A trick shot where the player hits the ball behind their back, typically used as a defensive measure when chasing down a lob or difficult shot. This shot is executed by reaching behind one's body to make contact with the ball when the standard position isn't possible.
cantilever: A move where the skater travels along a deep edge with knees bent, bending their back backwards parallel to the ice. Look for the skater's upper body leaning back toward the ice surface while gliding.
invisible knot: A method for joining new yarn to your project that creates a secure connection without visible knots. This technique is especially useful for changing colors or adding new yarn. Look for the smooth transition between yarns with no visible join or bulky knot.
lifting: A subtractive technique where partially dried or fully dried paint is removed from the surface using a damp brush, sponge, or cloth. This technique allows artists to create highlights, lighten areas, or correct mistakes by physically removing pigment from the paper or canvas. Lifting works best on non-staining pigments and papers that allow reactivation of paint. Look for areas where color appears lighter or has been removed entirely to create highlights or texture.
heel walking: Assessing balance and specific muscle strength (dorsiflexors) by having the person walk a short distance only on their heels, keeping the forefoot and toes off the ground. Look for: the person walking with weight only on their heels; note their balance and ability to keep the front of the feet elevated.
simple interrupted suture: The most basic stitch: the needle passes once through both wound edges, the suture is tied with a knot on the surface, and then cut; this is repeated as needed along the wound. Look for: a series of individual stitches crossing the wound perpendicularly, each with its own knot visible on the surface.
athetosis: A type of involuntary movement (which is movement not consciously controlled by the person) characterized by slow, continuous, twisting, and writhing motions that flow into one another. These movements often affect the distal limbs (hands and feet) and sometimes the face, tongue, or trunk. Look for: slow, non-stop, snake-like or twisting movements, especially in the fingers, hands, toes, or face, that seem purposeless and merge together smoothly.
pureeing: A process where food is mashed, blended, or ground until it becomes a completely smooth, uniform paste or liquid with no discernible solid pieces. This technique is typically performed using a food processor, blender, or food mill to break down all fibers and solids. Look for the transformation of chunky ingredients into a silky, consistent texture without any lumps or separate pieces.
tailslide: A slide trick where the skater ollie's (jumps with the board) onto an obstacle and slides with the tail (rear end of the board) on the edge or rail. Look for the back portion of the deck making contact while the nose is elevated.
figure four: An advanced technique where the climber hooks one leg over the arm on the same side, creating a "figure 4" shape that allows for exceptional reach on steep terrain. The climber uses the leg as leverage to pull their body higher than would be possible with arm strength alone. Look for a climber's leg wrapped over their arm in a complex interlocking position.
cattle crossing: A two-handed looping trick (2A) where yo-yos loop simultaneously with paths crossing each other, visually creating an “X” pattern. Distinct visually by intersecting loops, unlike parallel loops that don't cross paths.
increase / single crochet increase: A technique to add stitches to a row by working multiple stitches into the same stitch from the previous row. For single crochet increases, two or more single crochets are worked into the same stitch. Look for areas where the fabric widens or expands.
